U.S. GOVERNMENT PRINTING OFFICE: 1972

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"The 1970 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now
convened."
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR
Francis H. Kennedy, Jr., of St. Louis, Mo., Bernard J. McDonnell,
Jr., of River Grove, Ill., John G. Hicks, of Louisville, Ky., Robert M.
Jernigan, of Oklahoma City, Okla., and Leonard Clarence Mannas,
of Tulsa, Okla., on motion of Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Gris-
wold; Ronald J. Carlson, of Jamestown, N.Y., and Chester C. Lowe,
Jr., of Little Rock, Ark., on motion of Mr. John L. McClellan; Yard-
ley Drake Buckman, of Jacksonville, Fla., and James C. Rinaman.
Jr., of Jacksonville, Fla., on motion of Mr. Charles E. Bennett;
Thomas D. Benson, of Nashville, Tenn., on motion of Mr. David H.
Pryor; Charles E. Sandler, of Rockville, Md., on motion of Mr. Law-
rence J. Hogan; Richard Brickman, of Los Angeles, Calif., and
Patrick Lee Barnes, of Alhambra, Calif., on motion of Mr. Charles
E. Wiggins; Olney G. Wallis, of Llano, Tex., on motion of Mr. Omar
Burleson; Samuel Lee Stockman, of Mobile, Ala., on motion of Mr.
Tom Bevill; Herbert J. Brown, of Fort Worth, Tex., on motion of
Mr. Munson H. Lane; Thomas Edwards Abernathy, IV, of Chat-
tanooga, Tenn., on motion of Mr. James Thomas Martin: Janet
Lenora King, of Lakeland, Fla., on motion of Mr. A. R. Carver;
Alton Gifford Hall, of Springfield, Ill., on motion of Mr. Evan
Howell; Lindsey R. Jeanblanc, of New Braunfels, Tex., on motion of
Mr. James K. Jeanblanc; Iver J. Longeteig, III, of Meridian, Idaho,
on motion of Mr. James C. Morfitt; John Edward Hilliard, of Newton,
Tex., and Ernest J. Altgelt, III, of San Antonio, Tex., on motion of
Mr. Martin J. Linsky; Ramon J. Morganstern, of St. Louis, Mo.,
and Bruce T. Leitman, of Birmingham, Mich., on motion of Mr.
Francis Raymond Hammill, Jr.
430-278-70-1

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1970
2
William Bennett Thompson, of Detroit, Mich., on motion of Mr.
Richard F. Fellrath; Jerome D. Winegarden, of Flint, Mich., on mo-
tion of Mr. Robert Ira Waxman; Thomas Penfield Jackson, of Chevy
Chase, Md., on motion of Mr. Thomas S. Jackson; Ralph G. Pagter,
of Anaheim, Calif., on motion of Mr. Tyler Abell; J. Nicholas Mc-
Grath, Jr., of San Francisco, Calif., on motion of Mr. Daniel M.
Friedman; James C. Baggott, of Dayton, Ohio, on motion of Mr.
Ronald Gilbert Birch; A. H. Ehrgood, Jr., of Lebanon, Pa., on motion
of Mr. Shewin T. McDowell; Robert Atkin Calvert, of Denver, Colo.,
and David Ross Calvert, of Denver, Colo., on motion of Mr. John F.
Dee, Jr.; Herbert Stanley Ezrin, of Washington, D.C., Ronald D.
West, of Washington, D.C., Samuel N. Klewans, of Springfield, Va.,
Samuel M. Shapiro, of Washington, D.C., and Theodore Kligman,
of Silver Spring, Md., on motion of Mr. F. Joseph Donohue; Milton
S. Winters, of Princeton, N. J., on motion of Mr. Roland A. Linger;
Henry H. McVey, III, of Richmond, Va., on motion of Mr. Robert
Bruce Carter; Julius LeVonne Chambers, of Charlotte, N.C., Norman
J. Chachkin, of New York, N.Y., and John Fako, Jr., of Chicago, Ill.,
on motion of Mr. Lawrence Gerald Wallace; Charles F. Cottam,
of Providence, R.I., on motion of Mr. John H. Davitt; Phoebe Nan
Matthews, of Chevy Chase, Md., on motion of Mr. Robert Worley,
Jr.; James J. McCarthy, of Los Angeles, Calif., on motion of Mr.
Arthur J. Keeffe; Ignatius Semmes Luckett, of Clarksdale, Miss., on
motion of Mr. Frank Roberson; John Maguire Dowd, of Boston,
Mass., on motion of Mr. George F. Lynch; David A. Oxford, of Tus-
caloosa, Ala., George W. Hargraves, of Pocatello, Idaho, and James
Thomas Jones, of Eden, Idaho, on motion of Mr. Emery David Doane,
Jr.; Edward Patrick Burns, of Fargo, N. Dak., on motion of Mr.
Hugh J. Kelly; and Milburn D. Moore, Sr., of Philadelphia, Miss.,
on motion of Mr. Peter M. Stockett, were admitted to practice.
Adjourned until Monday, October 12, 1970, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, October 12,1970, will be as follows: Nos.
281, 349, and 444 (and 498).
☑

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
3
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 43, Original. State of Oregon, plaintiff, v. John N. Mitchell,
Attorney General of the United States. The motion for leave to file.
the bill of complaint is granted. The motion of the New York City
Board of Elections for leave to intervene in this case and in No. 44,
Original is denied. The motion of Youth Franchise Coalition et al.,
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, in this case
and in No. 46, Original is denied.
No. 44, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. John N. Mitchell,
Attorney General of the United States. The motion for leave to file
the bill of complaint is granted. The motion of the State of Indiana
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
The motion of the State of Indiana for leave to join the State of
Arkansas et al. in amicus curiae brief of State of Indiana is granted.
No. 46, Original. United States, Plaintiff, v. State of Arizona.
The motion for leave to file the bill of complaint is granted. The
motion of defendant for permission for two attorneys for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument is granted.
No. 47, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Idaho. The
motion for leave to file the bill of complaint is granted. The motion
of the Commonwealth of Virginia for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 281. James E. Swann et al., petitioners, v. Charlotte-Mecklen-
burg Board of Education et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in the oral argument in this case and in No. 349,
as amicus curiae, is granted and thirty minutes are allotted for that
purpose. An additional fifteen minutes is allotted to each side in these
cases and the cases are consolidated with a total of three hours for oral
argument. The motions of the National Education Association;
William C. Cramer; and The Governor of Florida for leave to par-
ticipate in the oral argument, as amicus curiae, are denied. The motion
of The Classroom Teachers Association of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg
School System, Inc., for leave to participate in oral argument, as
amicus curiae, in this case and in No. 349, is denied. The motions of
the Commonwealth of Virginia; and the Attorney General of Florida
430-278-70--2

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1970
4
for leave to participate in the oral argument, as amicus curiae, are
denied: The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Harlan and
Mr. Justice Marshall dissent from the denial of the latter motions.
The motion of Newton Collier Estes for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted, but the motion for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. The motion of Albert W. Watson
et al., for leave to join in the amicus curiae brief of William C. Cramer
is granted. The motion of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Edu-
cation for an ancillary writ of certiorari in this case and in No. 349
pertaining to the proceedings subsequent to the granting of certiorari
in No. 281 is granted and treating the motion as a petition for a writ
of certiorari it is also granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 444. Mrs. Robert Lee Moore et al., appellants, v. Charlotte-
Mecklenburg Board of Education et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of North Carolina. Further
consideration of the question of jurisdiction in this case postponed
to the hearing of the case on the merits. Case consolidated with No. 498
for oral argument. One hour allotted for oral argument for the
appellees in No. 498 and a similar amount of time allotted to all of
the other parties in both cases. Cases set for oral argument immediately
following No. 349. Motion of appellants as to scheduling oral argu-
ment and apportionment of time denied.
No. 498. North Carolina State Board of Education et al., appel-
lants, v. James E. Swann et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of North Carolina. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted. Motion of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of
Education to join in appeal granted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 349. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education et al., peti-
tioners, v. James E. Swann et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 420. Charles McDaniel, Superintendent of Schools, et al., pe-
titioners v. Joseph Barresi, Jr., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Georgia granted and case set for oral argument
immediately following No. 498. Motion of State of Georgia for leave
to participate in oral argument, amicus curiae, denied. The Chief
Justice, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Harlan, and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall dissent from the denial of the motion.
No. 436. Birdie Mae Davis et al., petitioners, v. Board of School
Commissioners of Mobile County et al. Motion for leave to supplement
petition and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1970
5
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Case set for oral argument
immediately following No. 420. Motion of Solicitor General for
additional time for oral argument granted and thirty minutes allotted
for that purpose. An additional fifteen minutes allotted to each side.
Motion of State of Mississippi for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment, as amicus curiae, denied. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Black,
Mr. Justice Harlan, and Mr. Justice Marshall dissent from the denial
of this motion. Motion of respondents Mobile County Council Parent-
Teachers Association et al., for additional time for oral argument
denied, except as indicated above, and permission granted for two
attorneys to participate in oral argument for the respondents.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for the week beginning November 30,
1970, and for such further time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
ORDER
It is ordered that William M. Allison be, and he hereby is, appointed
a Deputy Clerk of this Court.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
6
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 281. James E. Swann et al., petitioners, v. Charlotte-Mecklen-
burg Board of Education et al. The motion of Charles E. Bennett for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of Charles
E. Bennett for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae,
is denied.
-
No. . Don B. Pratt and Luther J. Wilson, appellants, v. Leila
Begley, Secretary of State of Kentucky, et al. The application for in-
junction pending appeal presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
430-278-70-3

MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
7
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 297. E. Michael McCann, District Attorney of Milwaukee
County, appellant, v. Sidney G. Babbitz. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin. The ap-
peal is dismissed. Opinion per curiam.
No. 350. The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner et al., petitioners, v.
Ralph E. Kennedy et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of The
Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. Motion to defer consideration of petition
for certiorari denied. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, orders
vacated, and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California with directions to dismiss the case
as moot. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions and petition.
No. 5156. Dudley George Hanemann, petitioner, v. Florida. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further con-
sideration in light of Ashe v. Swenson, Warden, 397 U.S. 436. Opinion
per curiam.
No. 5191. Thomas Hall, petitioner, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Alabama with directions to dismiss the motion
as moot. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 114. Corlon C. Keller, appellant, v. Department of Alcoholic
Beverage Control of the State of California. Appeal from the Court
430-278-70-4

8
of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 170. Louis Weiner dba Louis Weiner Real Estate Co., et al.,
appellants, v. State Real Estate Commission of the State of Nebraska.
Appeal from Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 218. Loren B. Belker, appellant, v. Board of Educational
Lands and Funds et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 220. Chester F. Jacobs, as County Treasurer of the County
of Suffolk, et al., appellants, v. William Rogers et al.; and
No. 221. Pact Realty Corp., appellant, v. William Rogers et al.
Appeals from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeals are dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peals were taken as petitions for writs of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 234. William E. Goetz et al., appellants, v. Board of Regents,
State Senior Colleges, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiarari, certiorari is denied.

Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for a writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers

whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,

No. 5296. Olen Winston Melton, appellant, v. Tom Lawson McCall
et al. Appeal from Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is dis-

appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is

No. 119. Cora McKinnon, appellant, v. Willie Brown. Appeal from
the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California, Coun-
ty of Riverside. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that further consideration of the question of jurisdiction
should be postponed to a hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 159. Rudy Rios, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from the Court of
Civil Appeals of Texas, Fourth Supreme Judicial District. The ap-
peal is dismissed. Mr. Justice Black is of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 223. Southland Racing Corporation, appellant, v. Porter
Rodgers et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 418. H. H. Robertson Co. and Liberty Mutual Insurance Co.,
appellants, v. Kenneth Newberry, etc. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 256. First Mercantile Consumer Discount Company, appellant,
v. Anthony E. Stefanelli et al.; and
No. 257. Oxford Consumer Discount Company of North Philadel-
phia, appellant, v. Anthony E. Stefanelli et al. Appeals from the Su-
preme Court of New Jersey. The appeals are dismissed. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the opinion that probable juris-
diction should be noted.
No. 357. William Pate et al., appellants, v. El Paso County, Texas,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Texas. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 482. Nelson A. Rockefeller, Governor of the State of New York,
et al., appellants, v. Socialist Workers Party et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1970
10
The judgment is affirmed and the stay order of Mr. Justice Harlan
vacated. The Chief Judge, Mr. Justice Harlan, and Mr. Justice Stew-
art dissent from the affirmance of the judgment and are of the opinion
that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 5425. Joe Jones, Jr., appellant, v. California. Appeal from
the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California, County
of Los Angeles. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 853. In Matter of Disbarment of Russell L. Wolden. It is
ordered that Russell L. Wolden, of San Francisco, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue.
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

opinion that the stays should be continued.

Attorney General of the United States;

No. 46, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Arizona; and
No. 47, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Idaho. The

MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1970
11
motion of the Solicitor General to consolidate these cases for oral
argument is granted. The motion of Frederick J. Christopher, Jr.,
et al., for leave to intervene and participate in oral argument in No.
46, Original is denied.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff v.
State of New York et al. The motion of the State of Connecticut
for leave to intervene as a party plaintiff is granted.
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that John F. Davis, Esquire, of Washing-
ton, D.C., be, and he is hereby, appointed Special Master in this
case with authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of
additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with
authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evi-
dence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it necessary
to call for. The master is directed to submit such reports as he may
deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him,
the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court hereafter may direct.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that if the position of Special Master in
this case becomes vacant during a recess of Court, the Chief Justice
shall have the authority to make a new designation which shall
have the same effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
No. 41, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Wyandotte Chemicals
Corporation et al. This case is set for oral argument on the motion for
leave to file the bill of complaint and the responses thereto. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing the views of
the United States and to participate in the oral argument, as amicus
curiae.

parties are requested to file further memoranda on the following
questions: (1) Must Congress authorize or ratify the withdrawal of
territorial lands by the President?, (2) If so, did Executive Order
No. 8979 have the necessary authorization or ratification?, and (3)
Was this matter adequately raised below?

supplemental briefs on the question of the residence of each of the
litigants at the time of the instigation of this litigation.

SUPERFOR

ORDER
It is ordered that the Rules of the Supreme Court of the United
States be and the same are hereby amended by deleting Rule 5, en-
titled "Admission to the Bar", and substituting in its place the
following:
5.
ADMISSION TO THE BAR
1. It shall be requisite to the admission of attorneys or counsellors.
to practice in this court, that they shall have been such for three
years past in the highest court of a State, Territory, District, Com-
monwealth, or Possession, and that their private and professional char-
acters shall appear to be good.
2. Each applicant shall file with the clerk (1) a certificate from the
presiding judge or clerk of the proper court evidencing his admission
to practice there and that he is presently in good standing, and (2)
his personal statement, on the form approved by the court and fur-
nished by the clerk, which shall be endorsed by two members of the
bar of this court who are not related to the applicant.
3. If the documents submitted by the applicant demonstrate that
he possesses the necessary qualifications, the clerk shall so notify the
applicant and he may be admitted without appearing in court. Upon
the applicant's signing the oath or affirmation and paying the fee re-
quired under Rule 52 (d), the clerk shall issue a certificate of admission
to the applicant. However, if the applicant so elects he may be ad-
mitted on oral motion by a member of the bar in open court, pro-
vided the applicant has satisfied the requirements for admission.
4. Each applicant shall take or subscribe the following oath or af-
firmation, viz:
---9
I₁
do solemnly swear (or affirm) that as an at-
torney and as a counsellor of this court I will conduct myself upright-
ly, and according to law, and that I will support the Constitution of the
United States.

concluded by Mr. Jack Greenberg for the petitioners.
No. 14. North Carolina, appellant, v. Henry C. Alford. Reargued
by Mr. Jacob L. Safron for the appellant and by Mrs. Doris R. Bray
for the appellee.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
58
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 160. United States, appellant, v. Maryland Savings-Share In-
surance Corporation. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Maryland. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of Maryland for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Harlan, considering that the issues
in this case are deserving of plenary consideration, would set the case
for argument.
No. 175. Joseph Colombo, petitioner, v. New York. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals of New York for further consideration in light
of Waller v. Florida, 397 U.S. 387. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice
Black is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted and judg-
ment reversed.
No. 386. United States et al., appellants, v. City of Chicago et al.;
No. 387. United States et al., appellants, v. Tennessee Public Serv-
ice Commission et al.;
No. 396. Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, appellant, v.
Tennessee Public Service Commission et al.; and
No. 410. Chicago & Eastern Illinois Railroad et al., appellants, v.
City of Chicago et al. Appeals from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgments reversed and cases
remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Harlan with whom Mr. Justice Black joins.
430-278-70-13

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1970
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
59
No. 451. Tilden W. Johnson, appellant, v. State Bar of California
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 588. Pop Poppenheimer et al., appellants, v. Tennessee et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Tennessee. The appeal is dismissed. Schackman v. Arnebergh,
387 U.S. 427.
No. 704. Ramsay Wood et al., appellants, v. Felix Putterman et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Stewart are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration of deci-
sion of this appeal.
No. 5354. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. Lyndon B. Johnson et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit. Motion of the appellants to strike scandalous matter denied. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this appeal and motion.
No. 5480. Roy Anderson, appellant, v. Knott Hotels Corporation
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Motion to postpone case denied. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in the oral

The appellee is allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.

las took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

motion of the respondent for enlargement of time for oral argument
is denied.

tioners, v. Rederiaktiebolaget Transatlantic. The motion of the Solici-

curiae, in support of the petitioner is granted and twenty minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The respondent is granted twenty additional
minutes for oral argument.

petitioners, v. Harper & Row Publishers, Inc., et al. The motion of the
petitioners to advance is denied. The motion of the State Bar of Texas
for leave to join in the amicus curiae brief of American Bar Associa-
tion is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of these motions.

pany. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
the oral argument, as amicus curiae, on behalf of the petitioner is
denied. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 26, 1970, until
Monday, November 9, 1970.

430-278-70-18

MONDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
74
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 5272. John Thompson, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Louisiana for consideration of the request contained in the memo-
randum filed by the Solicitor General. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Jus-
tice Black, with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins, would grant
certiorari and reverse the decision below for the reasons stated in his
dissenting opinions in Abbate v. U.S., 359 U.S. 187, 201 (1959), and
Bartkus v. Illinois, 359 U.S. 121, 150 (1959).
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 5811. Roy Anderson, appellant, v. American Broadcasting
Company et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of New York. The application for stay present-
ed to Mr. Justice Harlan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 1109, Oct. Term, 1968. Edna Weed, petitioner, v. Owen
Bilbrey, Sr., et al. The respondents are requested to file a response
within 30 days to the motion for leave to file a third petition for
rehearing. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 31, Orig. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. The re-
port of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Exceptions,
any, with supporting briefs, shall be filed within sixty days.

No. 121. Richard Mayberry, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania. The mo-
tion of Carol Mary Los for leave to participate in the oral argument,
pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 420. Charles McDaniel, Superintendent of Schools, et al., pe-
titioners, v. Joseph Barresi, Jr., et al. The motion of the respondents
for leave to file a brief after argument is granted.
No. 712. Triangle Improvement Council et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam S. Ritchie, Commissioner, State Road Commission of West
Virginia, et al. The application for an injunction pending disposition
of the petition for a writ of certiorari presented to the Chief Justice,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that the application should be granted.
No. 799. Glenda M. Cocanower, appellant, v. Paul N. Marston, In-
dividually and as Recorder for Maricopa County, et al. The motion
to advance and expedite hearing is denied.

expedite consideration of the petition for certiorari is denied.

Secretary of State of Alabama, et al. The application for continuance
of stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the
Court is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the appli-
cation should be granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this application.
No. 5875. Roy Anderson, appellant, v. Nelson A. Rockefeller et al.
The motion to advance is denied. The application for stay presented
to Mr. Justice Harlan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 507. California Department of Human Resources Development
et al., appellants, v. Judith Java et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California. In this case
probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 5714. Linda Jenness, et al., appellants, v. Ben W. Fortson,
Secretary of State of Georgia. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Georgia. Motion to advance is
denied. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. In
this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

Reed (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court

81
of Claims beginning October 5, 1970, and ending June 30, 1971, and
for such further times as may be required to complete unfinished busi-
ness, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the min-
utes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

430-278-70-22

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1970
89
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 300. Eddie Odom, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 412. Kal W. Lines, Trustee, etc., petitioner, v. Kenneth Robert
Frederick and Clarence Harris. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion
of respondent Harris to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Motion
of respondent Frederick to dispense with printing brief in opposition
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted and judgment affirmed.
Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. The
Chief Justice is of the opinion that petition for writ of certiorari
should be denied.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 254. The Parish School Board of the Parish of St. Charles
et al., appellants, v. Frank T. Stewart et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The judg-
ment is affirmed, City of Phoenix v. Kolodziejski, 399 U.S. 204. Mr.
Justice Harlan is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 540. Willis H. Bower, Superintendent, Arizona State Hospital,
appellant, v. William Price Vaughan et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Arizona. The motion of the
appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The judg-
ment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Harlan, and Mr. Jus-
tice White are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
430-278-70-23.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1970
90
No. 679. Seymour Friedman, appellant, v. Maurice J. O'Rourke
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 5387. Iris Iona Smith, appellant, v. Iowa Liquor Control
Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction
should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 5531. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. Fred E. Gerken et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The motion to strike scandalous matter is denied. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion and appeal.
No. 5652. Helmut Lehman, appeallant, v. California. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Cali-
fornia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No.-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Daniel Annunziata, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him
referred to the court, is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in
the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 42, Original. Commonwealth of Massachusetts, plaintiff, v.
Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense. The motion of The Constitu-
tional Lawyers' Committee on Undeclared War for leave to file a
supplemental brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of John
M. Wells et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, to participate
in oral argument, or alternative motion to be named as parties plain-
tiff, is denied. The motion for leave to file bill of complaint is denied.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Harlan and
Mr. Justice Stewart dissent.
No. 71. Samuel J. Abate, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Paul F. Mundt
et al. The motion of the petitioners for leave for three attorneys to
participate in oral argument is granted.
No. 203. Dennis Councle McGautha, petitioner, v. California. The
motion for the appointment of counsel to represent the petitioner is
granted. The motion of Luke McKissack for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1970
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
91
No. 573. Claude R. Kirk, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Robert H.
Hargrave et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Florida. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.
No. 569. John R. Earley et al., appellants, v. Joan DiCenso et al.;
and
No. 570. William P. Robinson, Jr., Commissioner of Education of
the State of Rhode Island, et al., appellants, v. Joan DiCenso et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of
Rhode Island. In these cases probable jurisdiction is noted. Cases con-
solidated and a total of one and one half hours allotted for oral argu-
ment. Cases set for oral argument immediately following Nos.
89 and 153.
No. 5161. Frank Johnson, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion of appellant for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction
is noted.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 203. Dennis Councle McGautha, petitioner, v. California. One
and one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Herman
F. Selvin for the petitioner, by Mr. Ronald M. George for the respond-
ent and by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the United
States, as amicus curiae, at the invitation of the Court.
No. 204. James Edward Crampton, petitioner, v. Ohio. One and
one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. John J.
Callahan for the petitioner, by Mr. Melvin L. Resnick for the respond-
ent and by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the United
States, as amicus curiae, at the invitation of the Court.
No. 97. Ralph Piccirillo, petitioner, v. New York. Argued by Miss
Malvine Nathanson for the petitioner and by Mr. Stanley M. Meyer
for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Tuesday, November 10, 1970, will be as follows:
Nos. 80, 55, 58, and 63.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1970
113
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.- John Daniel Ferrell, petitioner, v. Selective Service
Local Board No. 38 of Walnut Ridge, Arkansas, et al. The application
for stay of induction and recall of the mandate of the USCA, Second
Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 87. United States, petitioner, v. District Court in and for the
County of Eagle and State of Colorado et al.; and
No. 812. United States, petitioner, v. The District Court in and for
Water Division No. 5, State of Colorado, et al. The application of the
Solicitor General, consented to by all parties concerned, for a stay
of the Colorado State Court proceedings before the District Court in
and for Water Division No. 8, presented to Mr. Justice White, and
by him referred to the Court, is granted insofar as such proceedings
involve an adjudication of the rights of the United States, pending
the decision of this Court in No. 87, and in No. 812 presently pend-
ing on a petition for a writ of certiorari.
Х
430-278-70-28

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1970
114
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 584. Durwood T. Pye, appellant, v. State Highway Depart-
ment of Georgia et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 592. Montgomery Ward & Co., Incorporated, appellant, v.
Franchise Tax Board of the State of California. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 5676. Juan Macias et al., appellants, v. Elliot Richardson, Sec-
retary of Health, Education, and Welfare, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of California.
The judgment is affirmed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 35, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine et al.
The motion of the State of Florida for severance is referred to the
Special Master. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 28. Lelia Mae Sanks et al., appellants, v. Georgia et al. Further
consideration of the appellees' suggestion of mootness is postponed to
the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 89. Alton J. Lemon et al., appellants, v. David H. Kurtzman,
as Superintendent of Public Instruction of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania, et al.; and
No. 153. Eleanor Taft Tilton et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Rich-
ardson, Secretary of the United States Department of Health, Educa-
430-278-70- -29

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1970
115
tion, and Welfare, et al. The motion of The National Jewish Commis-
sion on Law and Public Affairs et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, is granted.
No. 128. In re Barbara Burrus et al., petitioners. The motion of the
respondent for leave for two attorneys to participate in oral argument
is granted.
No. 154. Ronald James et al., appellants, v. Anita Valtierra et al.,
and
No. 226. Virginia C. Shaffer, appellant, v. Anita Valtierra et al.
The motions of The American Jewish Congress et al.; The NAACP
Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., et al.; and The National
Urban Coalition et al., for leave to file briefs, as amici curiae, are
denied. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion
that the motions should be granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 336. Louis S. Nelson, Warden, petitioner, v. Joe J. B. O'Neil.
The application of respondent for release on personal recognizance and
separate petition for a writ of habeas corpus presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, are denied.
No. 360. Grove Press, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Anthony B. Flask
et al. The motion of Eve Productions, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit during the week of Jan-
uary 18, 1971, and for such further time as may be required to com-
plete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered
entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1970

121
The Court will take a recess from Monday, November 23, 1970,
until Monday, December 7, 1970.

No. Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. John A. Volpe, Secretary, Department of Transportation,

430-278-70- -33

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1970
127
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 541. Arturo Fornaris, Jr., appellant, v. The Ridge Tool Co.,
et al.; and
No. 543. Puerto Rico, appellant, v. The Ridge Tool Co., et al. Ap-
peals from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit with directions to remand to the
United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico with
instructions to hold its hand until the Puerto Rican Supreme Court has
authoritatively ruled on the local law question in light of the federal
claims. Opinion per curiam.
No. 602. Arnold Tours, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. William B.
Camp, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States.
District Court for the District of Massachusetts for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Harlan would set the case
for oral argument.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 1385, Oct. Term, 1969. Reginald Hutcherson, et al., appel-
lants, v. Laurie Lehtin, et al. The petition for rehearing is granted and
the order of June 29, 1970, is vacated. The judgment is recalled and
a new judgment is entered vacating the judgment of the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California and case re-
manded to that court so that it may enter a fresh order dismissing the
complaint, thus affording the appellants an opportunity to take a
timely appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit.
430-278-70- -34

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1970
128
No. 256. First Mercantile Consumer Discount Company, appellant,
v. Anthony E. Stefanelli, et al. Treating the petition for rehearing
as a motion to amend the order of this Court dated October 12, 1970,
the motion is granted. The order is amended to read "The appeal is
dismissed for want of a final judgment."
No. 626. William R. Sterrett, Administrator, Indiana Department
of Public Welfare, et al. appellants, v. Esther A. Grubb, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Indiana. The motion of appellee Grubb for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Black and
Mr. Justice Harlan dissent. They are of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 631. Southern Pacific Transportation Company, appellant, v.
United States, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Colorado. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 5697. Betty Ruth Herring, appellant, v. R. L. Mathis Certified
Dairy Company, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 5724. Russell Porter and Gerald Gordon, appellants, v. New
York. Appeal from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of
New York, First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 508. California, petitioner, v. William Pinkus. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit granted and judgment affirmed by an equally divided
court. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 5398. Parker Hemphill, petitioner, v. Bernard T. Moynahan,
Jr. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further considera-
tion in light of Price v. Georgia, 398 U.S.,323.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The motion of the State of California for
leave to intervene as a party plaintiff is referred to the Special Master
for his recommendation.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1970
129
No. 30. United States, petitioner, v. Roosevelt Hudson Harris. The
motion of Americans for Effective Law Enforcement, Inc., for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 43. Earl Faircloth et al., appellants, v. Matthew B. Lazarus.
The motion of Stephen Hillardt and Timothy Green for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motions of Stephen Hillardt
and Timothy Green for leave to intervene as parties appellee and to
expedite appeal are denied.
No. 59. National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., petitioner,
v. Securities and Exchange Commission et al.; and
No. 61. Investment Company Institute et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam B. Camp, Comptroller of the Currency, et al. The motion to re-
verse sequence of oral argument or alternative request that the cases be
consolidated is denied. The Chief Justice took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this motion.
No. 83. Garrett H. Byrne, etc., et al., appellants, v. Serafim Kara-
lexis et al. The motion of the appellees for leave to file a supplemental
memorandum, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 206. Viven Harris, petitioner, v. New York. The motion of
Frank S. Hogan for leave to participate in the oral argument, as
amicus curiae, is granted. However, counsel for the respondent will
cede fifteen minutes of his time for that purpose.
No. 507. California Department of Human Resources Develop-
ment et al., appellants, v. Judith Java et al. The motion of the
Southern California Edison Company et al. for leave to intervene as
parties appellant is denied without prejudice to the filing of a brief,
as amici curiae, with consents of the parties, or a motion for leave to
file a brief, as amici curiae, if the consents are not granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 246. Albert B. Muir III, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First
District, denied.
No. 377. Paul F. Perati, petitioner, v. Superior Court of California,
County of Alameda. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of

133
No. 5733. Fred A. Jewell, petitioner, v. City of Covington et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals.
for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 5734. Earl E. Kaldenberg, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 601. John Keriakos et al., petitioners, v. Joseph L. Hunt et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit denied. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Harlan and
Mr. Justice Blackmun, for the reasons expressed in their separate
opinions in Cain v. Kentucky, 397 U.S. 319 (1970), Walker v. Ohio,
398 U.S. 434 (1970) (The Chief Justice); Roth v. United States, 354
U.S. 476, 496 (1957), Jacobellis v. Ohio, 378 U.S. 184, 203 (1964),
Memoirs v. Massachusetts, 383 U.S. 413, 455 (1966) (Mr. Justice
Harlan); and Hoyt v. Minnesota, 399 U.S. 524 (1970) (Mr. Justice
Blackmun), would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment below,
and remand the case to the Court of Appeals for consideration of the
other issues tendered by petitioners. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 612. William R. Scaggs, petitioner, v. Stanley Larsen, Com-
manding General, Sixth United States Army, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 620. Cleona Hooper, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 639. Walter Grooms, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 640. Cleona Hooper, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 5790. Drury Whitlock, petitioner, v. United States. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.
No. 621. Indianapolis Newspapers, Inc., petitioner, v. Robert H.
Fields. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of In-
diana denied. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 5365. Clarence N. S. Shak, petitioner, v. Hawaii. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Hawaii denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 5366. Clarence N. S. Shak, petitioner, v. Hawaii. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Hawaii denied. Mr. Jus-

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1970
134
tice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 624. William Bond Clifford, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion to dispense with
printing the petition is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 5727. Robert G. Warner, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 247. St. Michael and Archangel Russian Orthodox Greek
Catholic Church et al., petitioners, v. Peter Uhniat et al.;
No. 305. Skega Aktiebolag et al., petitioners, v. The B. F. Good-
rich Company;
No. 341. Lakewood Manufacturing Company, petitioner, v. The
Home Insurance Company of New York et al.;
No. 344. George G. Kilarjian et al., petitioners, v. United States, as
Owner of the USNS Blue Jacket;
No. 367. Lykes Bros. Steamship Co., Inc., petitioner, v. Hess Ship-
ping Corporation et al.;
No. 5200. Lloyd Rice, petitioner, v. Wilber B. Schmidt, Warden;
No. 5202. Arlie Jones, petitioner, v. William D. Salisbury, Super-
intendent, Chillicothe Correctional Institution;
No. 5211. Donnell Leonard Luster, petitioner, v. Howard H.
Cooksey; and
No. 5379. James Ralph Williamson, petitioner, v. California. Pe-
titions for rehearing denied.
OPINION
No. 14. North Carolina, appellant, v. Henry C. Alford. On appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Mr. Justice Black, while adhering to his belief that
United States v. Jackson, 390 U.S. 570, was wrongly decided, concurs
in the judgment and in substantially all of the opinion. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

The day call for Monday, December 7, 1970, will be as follows: Nos.
Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al. v. John A. Volpe,
Secretary, Department of Transportation, et al., 88, 26, 66, and 75.

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1970
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
150
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al., petitioner,
v. John A. Volpe, Secretary, Department of Transportation, et al.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to Wm. Bradford
Reynolds, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No.
-
-. Consolidation Coal Co., petitioner, v. South-East Coal
Co. The motion to postpone oral argument in Ramsey v. United Mine
Workers of America, No. 88, is denied.
☑
430-278-70-37

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1970
151
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice.
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stew-
art, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 593. The Cincinnati, New Orleans & Texas Pacific Railway
Company, et al., appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio. The
judgment is affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
= case.
No. 778. Various Articles of "Obscene" Merchandise, Fred Cherry,
claimant, appellant, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. The
appeal is dismissed.
No. 5753. Joe Wadlington, appellant, v. Marvin W. Mindes et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion that prob-
able jurisdiction should be noted.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 524. Owsley Stanley et al., petitioners, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, insofar
as it seeks review of the affirmance by the Court of Appeals of count
5 (possession count) of the convictions of petitioners, Stanley, Thomas,
and Massey. Judgment as to these three individuals vacated, insofar
as that count is concerned and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
so that it may consider the suggestions contained in the memo-
randum the Solicitor General filed here. By this remand this Court
intimates no view as to the merits of the Solicitor General's position.
In all other respects the petition for certiorari is denied. Dissenting
430-278-70--38

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1970
152
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Blackmun dissent and would deny certiorari.
No. 656. Nicolo Licata, petitioner, v. United States. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Upon consideration of the suggestion of mootness and an
examination of the entire record, petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Central District of California with directions
to dismiss the case as moot. Mr. Justice Black is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 89. Alton J. Lemon et al., appellants, v. David H. Kurtzman,
as Superintendent of Public Instruction of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania, et al. The motions of Appellees Schools; and Penn-
sylvania Association of Independent Schools for additional time for
oral argument are denied.
No. 485. Ace Hawthorne, Sr., petitioner, v. Illinois. The applica-
tion to stay effectiveness of the order denying certiorari is denied.
No. 5247. Barrington Joseph Johnson, petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of the petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that William J. Lippman, Esquire, of Washington,
D.C., a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed
to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
The Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 655. James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Local Union 6799, United Steel workers of America, AFL-CIO, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 812. United States, petitioner, v. The District Court in and
for Water Division No. 5, State of Colorado, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Colorado granted and case set
for oral argument immediately following No. 87.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 233. Mary Mohland, petitioner, v. Montana State Board of
Equalization et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Montana denied.

ORAL ARGUMENT
-
No. Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. John A. Volpe, Secretary, Department of Transportation,
et al. Argued on the application for stay pending petition for a writ of
certiorari by Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr., for the petitioners, by Mr.
William Bradford Reynolds for respondent, John A. Volpe, Secretary,
Department of Transportation, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court
and by Mr. J. Alan Hanover for respondent, Charles W. Speight,
Commissioner, Tennessee Department of Highways.
No. 88. George Ramsey and Leon Nunley, dba Leon Nunley Coal
Company, et al., petitioners, v. United Mine Workers of America.
Argued by Mr. John A. Rowntree for the petitioners and by Mr.
Edward Bennett Williams for the respondent.
No. 26. James Edmund Groppi, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Argued
by Mrs. Elizabeth B. DuBois for the appellant and by Mr. Sverre O.
Tinglum for the appellee.
No. 66. George A. Rosenbloom, petitioner, v. Metromedia, Inc.
Argument commenced by Mr. Ramsey Clark for the petitioner.
No. 1066. Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. John A. Volpe, Secretary, Department of Transportation,
et al. The application for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Stewart,
and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the issuance of
the judgment of this Court. Treating the application for a stay and
the briefs in opposition as a petition for a writ of certiorari and op-
position thereto, certiorari is granted and the case is set for oral argu-
ment on Monday, January 11, 1971. Briefs for the petitioners shall be
filed by December 21, 1970, and briefs for the respondents shall be
filed by January 4, 1971. These briefs may be typewritten if counsel
are unable to file printed briefs by these dates. The motions of the
Committee of 100 on the Federal City, Inc.; and the City of Memphis

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1970
178
et al., for leave to file briefs, as amici curiae, are granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of these matters.
No. . San Antonio Conservation Society et al., petitioners, v.
Texas Highway Department et al. The application for a stay pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Black, and by him referred to the Court, is
granted provided a petition for a writ of certiorari, before judgment,
is filed in this Court by December 14, 1970. The briefs opposing such
petition shall be filed by December 17, 1970. Both the petition for a writ
of certiorari and briefs in opposition may be submitted in typewritten
form.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Tuesday, December 8, 1970, will be as follows:
Nos. 66, 75, 92, 85, and 325.
Х

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1970
179
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.

OPINIONS
Movant
J. Strom Thurmond
J. Strom Thurmond
J. Strom Thuromnd
J. Strom Thurmond
Stuart J. Land
James Manahan
No. 99. Port of Boston Marine Terminal Association et al., peti-
tioners, v. Rederiaktiebolaget Transatlantic. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 25. Walter J. Hickel, Secretary of the Interior, petitioner, v.
The Oil Shale Corporation et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgments reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice White,
and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 78. Atlantic City Electric Company et al., appellants, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York; and
No. 106. Alabama Power Company et al., appellants, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgments affirmed by an equally divided court.
430-278-70-42

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1970
180
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 66. George A. Rosenbloom, petitioner, v. Metromedia, Inc.
Argument continued by Mr. Bernard G. Segal for the respondent and
concluded by Mr. Ramsey Clark for the petitioner.
No. 75. California, petitioner, v. Jonathan Todd Byers. Argued by

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1970
184
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 732. Alabama et al., appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 733. Max Rafferty et al., appellants, v. Kenneth P. MacKay
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California. The judgment is affirmed. Baggett v. Bullitt,
377 U.S. 360. Mr. Justice Harlan is of the opinion that probable juris-
diction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 5854. Audrey Rena Champs, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, 14th Supreme Judicial District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 41, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Wyandotte Chemicals
Corporation et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for allot-
ment of time for oral argument is granted and twenty minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The defendant is allotted twenty additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 30. United States, petitioner, v. Roosevelt Hudson Harris. The
motion of the respondent for the appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Steven M. Umin, Esquire, of Washington, D.C.,
a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 85. Guy Porter Gillette, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 325. Louis A. Negre, petitioner, v. Stanley R. Larsen et al.
The motion of George T. Altman for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted.
430-278-70-45

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1970
185
No. 113. Bernard M. Decker, United States District Judge, et al.,
petitioners, v. Harper & Row Publishers, Inc., et al. The motion of the
Northampton County, Pennsylvania, Bar Association for leave to join
in the brief of the American Bar Association, as amicus curiae, is
granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 281. James E. Swann et al., petitioners, v. Charlotte-Mecklen-
burg Board of Education et al. The motion of The Jackson Urban
League for leave to strike its name from amici curiae brief, is granted.
No. 336. Louis S. Nelson, Warden, petitioner, v. Joe J. B. O'Neil.
The motion of the respondent for the appointment of counsel is
granted, and it is ordered that James S. Campbell, Esquire, of Wash-
ington, D.C., a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 609. John O. Graham, Commissioner, Department of Public
Welfare State of Arizona, appellant, v. Carmen Richardson, etc. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona.
Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 727. William P. Sailer et al., appellants, v. Elsie Mary Jane
Leger and Beryl Jervis. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Motion of the appellees for
leave to proceed in forma papperis granted. In this case probable juris-
diction noted.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, December 21, 1970, until
Monday, January 11, 1971.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 107. Hazel Palmer et al., petitioners, v. Allen C. Thompson,
Mayor, City of Jackson, et al. One and one half hours allowed for oral
argument. Argued by Mr. Paul A. Rosen and Mr. William M. Kunstler
for the petitioners and by Mr. William F. Goodman, Jr., for the re-
spondents.
No. 124. Willie S. Griggs et al., petitioners, v. Duke Power Com-
pany. Argued by Mr. Jack Greenberg for the petitioners, by Mr.
George W. Ferguson, Jr., for the respondent and by Mr. Lawrence M.
Cohen for the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, as amicus
curiae.
No. 205. John Harry Bruno, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania. Argued
by Mr. Daniel L. Quinlan for the petitioner and by Mr. Milton O. Moss
for the respondent.
No. 59. National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., petitioner,
v. Securities and Exchange Commission et al. One and one half hours
allowed for oral argument. Argument commenced by Mr. Joseph B.
Levin for the petitioner and continued by Mr. Archibald Cox for re-
spondent First National City Bank.

OPINION
No. 10. A. L. Dutton, Warden, appellant, v. Alex S. Evans. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for consid-
eration of the other issues presented in the habeas corpus proceedings.
Mr. Justice Stewart announced the judgment of the Court and an
opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White, and
Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas,
and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 59. National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., petitioner,
v. Securities and Exchange Commission et al. Argument continued by
Mr. Archibald Cox for respondent First National City Bank, by Mr.
Danield M. Friedman for the United States, as amicus curiae, by
special leave of Court, and concluded by Mr. Joseph B. Levin for the
petitioner.

hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. G. Duane Vieth for
the petitioners, by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for respondent William B.
Camp, Comptroller of the Currency, and by Mr. Archibald Cox for
respondent First National City Bank.

by Mr. John L. Kilcullen for the respondent.
No. 98. Isiah Relford, petitioner, v. Commandant, U.S. Discipli-
nary Barracks, Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas. Argument commenced by
Mr. Judson W. Detrick for the petitioner.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 1101. Named Individual Members of the San Antonio Conser-
vation Society, petitioners, v. The Texas Highway Department, et al.
The stay heretofore granted by the Court on December 7, 1970, is
vacated. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan,
and Mr. Justice Marshall dissent from the entry of this order.

430-278-70-50

MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1970
205
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 741. Chase Brass and Copper Co., appellant, v. Franchise Tax
Board of the State of California. Appeal from the Court of Appeal
of California, First Appellate District. Motions of The Tax Execu-
tives Institute, Inc.; and The Financial Executives Institute for
leave to file briefs, as amicus curiae, granted Motion of The National
Association of Manufacturers of United States et al., for leave to
file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 744. Phillip Young, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 754. 8200 Realty Corporation et al., appellants, v. John V.
Lindsay, Mayor of the City of New York, et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 762. Tilden W. Johnson, appellant, v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber
Co. et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 5874. O. C. Snoddy, appellant, v. Robert E. McNair et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
South Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr.
Justice Stewart is of the opinion that the judgment should be affirmed.
430-278-70-51

MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1970
206
No. 5875. Roy Anderson, appellant, v. Nelson A. Rockefeller et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. The
motion of the Solicitor General for an extension of time to file ex-
ceptions and brief on the Report of the Special Master is granted and
the time extended to and including January 8, 1971. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 41, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Wyandotte Chemicals
Corporation et al. The motion to permit three attorneys to participate
in oral argument on behalf of the defendants is granted.
No. 338. Blonder-Tongue Laboratories, Inc., petitioner, v. Univer-
sity of Illinois Foundation et al. The motion of The Finney Company
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of The
Finney Company for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, is denied. The motion of respondent, University of Illinois
Foundation, to allow additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 5175. Adolfo Perez et ux., petitioners, v. David H. Campbell,
Superintendent, Motor Vehicle Division, Arizona Highway Depart-
ment, et al. The motion of Women's Center Legal Program et al., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 5257. Lou Bertha Labine, natural tutrix of minor child, Rita
Nell Vincent, appellant, v. Simon Vincent, Administrator of the Suc-
cession of Ezra Vincent. The motion of American Civil Liberties
Union for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 548. Herbert L. Ely, Individually and as Chairman of the
Democratic Party of Arizona, appellant, v. Gary Peter Klahr et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Arizona. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 286. Alaska et al., petitioners, v. United States et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 721. Transit Homes, Inc., petitioner, v. Anthony Mastropole
et ux. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South
Carolina denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted and judgment of the
Supreme Court of South Carolina reversed.
No. 1101. Named Individual Members of the San Antonio Con-
servation Society, petitioners, v. The Texas Highway Department
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Black with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan join.

Justice Black concurs. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
