OPINION
No. 43, Original. State of Oregon, plaintiff, v. John N. Mitchell,
Attorney General of the United States;
No. 44, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. John N. Mitchell,
Attorney General of the United States;
No. 46, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Arizona; and
No. 47, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Idaho. Judg-
ments entered. Justice Black announced the judgments of the Court in
an opinion expressing his own view of these cases. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas dissenting in part and concurring in part. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Marshall join concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Adjourned until Monday, January 11, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, January 11, 1971, will be as follows:
Nos. 1066, 345, 117, 143, and 84.
☑

FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1971
218
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. In the Matter of Application of Gary Hogan, petitioner.
The motion for leave to file a petition for a writ of mandamus and
stay presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. 6295. Peter St. Clair, petitioner, v. Selective Service Local
Board No. 35 in Brooklyn, New York, et al. The application for a stay
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.

430-278-71-53

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1971
219
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice.
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 115. Caesario Jimenez et al., appellants, v. Eugene Naff,
Yakima County Auditor, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Washington. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Washington for further consideration in light of Oregon
et al. v. Mitchell et al. (decided December 21, 1970) 400 U.S. —.
No. 137. United States et al., appellants, v. Chicago & Eastern
Illinois Railroad Company; and
No. 138. Illinois Commerce Commission et al., appellants, v.
Chicago & Eastern Illinois Railroad Company. Appeals from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois with directions to remand
to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a determination as to
whether the trains involved constitute an “intercity” service within
the meaning of Section 102 (5) of the Rail Passenger Service Act of
1970, P.L. 91–518.
No. 463. Sea Pak, a Division of W. R. Grace & Company, appellant,
v. Industrial, Technical and Professional Employees, Division of
National Maritime Union, AFL-CIO. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Jus-
tice Harlan is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 768. Gilbert Messer et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Richardson.
Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky. Upon
consideration of the suggestion of mootness and an examination of
the entire record, judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
430-278-71—54

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1971
220
States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky with direc-
tions to dismiss case as moot.
No. 789. City of Chicago et al., appellants, v. United States et al.;
No. 793. The Western Pacific Railroad Company, appellant, v. City
of Chicago et al.;
No. 794. Burlington Northern, Inc., et al., appellants, v. City of
Chicago et al.; and
No. 797. United States et al., appellants, v. City of Chicago et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois. That portion of the judgment appealed from in No. 789
affirmed. Those portions of the judgment appealed from in Nos.
793, 794, and 797 reversed and cases remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further pro-
ceedings. U.S. v. City of Chicago, 400 U.S. 8.
No. 809. The Attic Club, Inc., appellant, v. Texas Liquor Control
Board. Appeal from Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 5978. Nathaniel Washington, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 813. Annie Mary Timmons, appellant, v. The South Carolina
Tricentennial Commission et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
South Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 820. Dan Coit et al., appellants, v. William H. Green et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 6011. William V. Fowler, appellant, v. Tom Adams, Secretary
of State of Florida. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Middle District of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.
No. 828. Washington Telephone Company, appellant, v. Washing-
ton. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 836. Maarten Henkes et al., appellants, v. John H. Fisher et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1971
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
221
No. 5561. Luther Lilly, petitioner, v. A. T. Rundle, Superintendent,
State Correctional Institution. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to reinstate the
appeal in conformity with the suggestions filed by the respondent.
No. 5958. Hubert Hall Irvin, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit dismissed. Case and record referred to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further considera-
tion in accordance with the suggestion contained in the memorandum
filed by the Solicitor General.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 338. Blonder-Tongue Laboratories, Inc., petitioner, v. Univer-
sity of Illinois Foundation et al. The motion of The Automatic
Electric Company for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
The motions of The Automatic Electric Company and The American
Patent Law Association for leave to participate in the oral argument,
as amicus curiae, are denied. The motion of the petitoner for additional
time for oral argument is denied.
No. 360. Grove Press, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Anthony B. Flask
et al. The motion of Charles H. Keating, Jr., for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 362. Vincent Francis McGee, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to Wm. Bradford
Reynolds to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 464. Gainesville Utilities Department et al., petitioners, v.
Florida Power Corporation; and
No. 469. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida Power
Corporation. The motion of the American Public Power Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 5175. Adolfo Perez et ux., petitioners, v. David H. Campbell,
Superintendent, Motor Vehicle Division, Arizona Highway Depart-
ment, et al. The motion of The National Organization for Women
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 5257. Lou Bertha Labine natural tutrix of minor child, Rita
Nell Vincent, appellant, v. Simon Vincent, Administrator of the Suc-

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1971
222
cession of Ezra Vincent. The motion The Center on Social Welfare
Policy and Law for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
The joint motion to substitute Wilbur Vincent in place of Simon
Vincent, deceased, as the party appellee is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 557. United States, appellant, v. International Minerals &
Chemical Corporation. Certified appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Ohio. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
No. 821. United States, appellant, v. Greater Buffalo Press, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of New York. In this probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 577. United States, petitioner, v. Sandra Denise Johnson. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 740. James Edward Green, petitioner, v. Kentucky. Petition
for writ of certiorari to Court of Appeals of Kentucky, granted.
No. 785. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The Nat-
ural Gas Utility District of Hawkins County, Tennessee. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit granted.
No. 5250. James Herman Bostic, petitioner, v. United States. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
granted.
No. 5485. Robert Johnson, petitioner, v. Mississippi. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Mississippi granted.
No. 783. Cassius Marsellus Clay, Jr., also known as Muhammad
Ali, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted limited
to Question 4 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"4. Whether petitioner's conviction should be vacated in light of this
Court's decision in Welsh v. United States, 398 U.S. 333 (1970), be-
cause the denial to petitioner of a conscientious objector exemption
may have been based upon the Department of Justice's erroneous.
characterization of his objections to participation in war as "political
and racial" rather than "religious?"

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1971
223
Mr. Justice Brennan is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted limited to Questions 1, 2 and 4 presented by the petition. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.

No. 69. George K. Wyman, Individually and as Commissioner of
the State of New York, Department of Social Services, appellant, v.
Barbara James, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York with directions to enter a judgment of dis-
missal. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice White concurs
in the judgment and joins the opinion of the Court with the exception
of Part IV thereof. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 40. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Local 825,
International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL-CIO; and
No. 42. Burns and Row, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Local 825, Inter-
national Union of Operating Engineers, AFL-CIO. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins.

OPINIONS
No. 46. Ernest Perkins et al., appellants, v. L. S. Matthews, Mayor
of the City of Canton, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the South-
ern District of Mississippi with instructions to issue injunctions re-
straining the further enforcement of the changes until such time as the
appellees adequately demonstrate compliance with § 5, and for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins concurring in the judgment of re-
versal and in the order of remand. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Black.
No. 55. Winton M. Blount, Postmaster General of the United
States, et al., appellants, v. Tony Rizzi dba The Mail Box. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Central District of
California; and
No. 58. United States et al., appellants, v. The Book Bin. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr.
Justice Black concurs in the result.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. . Carl Bruce Harris, petitioner, v. Texas. The motion
of the State of Texas to terminate petitioner's stay of execution is
denied. The motion of the petitioner that the Court consider his
motion for stay of execution as a petition for a writ of certiorari is
granted and the case is placed on the docket as No. 6458.

MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1971
253
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 5370. Robert Kennerly and Helen Kennerly, petitioners, v.
District Court of the Ninth Judicial District of Montana et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Montana. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Montana for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice White joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 843. John C. Luzaitis and Alfonso Sabino, appellants, v. Mu-
nicipal Court of Los Angeles Judicial District, County of Los Angeles,
State of California. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 851. Dominic Strazzula, appellant, v. Building Inspector of
Wellesley et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 5745. Peni Bates, appellant, v. Martin P. Catherwood, Indus-
trial Commissioner. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for wirt of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 5912. Kathleen Ramos et al., appellants, v. John C. Mont-
gomery et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of California. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.
430-278-71—61

MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1971
254
No. 5993. Lula Mae Conner et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Richard-
son, Secretary, Health, Education and Welfare, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. The
judgment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 326. Erlene Crosslin et vir, petitioners, v. The Mountain
States Telephone and Telegraph Company. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Motion of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of Arizona for re-
consideration in light of the suggestions contained in the brief of the
Solicitor General, as amicus curiae, filed November 19, 1970. By this
remand this Court intimates no view as to the merits of the Solicitor
General's position. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 5788. L. C. Smith, petitioner, v. United States. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Motion for leave to amend petition granted. Motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Ohio for reconsideration in light
of the suggestion contained in the Solicitor General's memorandum
filed December 16, 1970.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 1112, Oct. Term, 1968. William Leighton, etc., petitioner, v.
The One William Street Fund, Inc., et al. Motion for relief pendente
lite denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion. Motion for leave to file second petition for
rehearing denied. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
the latter motion.
No. . Roy Anderson, petitioner, v. Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller,
Governor, et al. The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice
Harlan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 144. Eugene Griffin, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Lavon Brecken-
ridge et al. The motion of the respondents for the appointment of
counsel is granted, and it is ordered that W. D. Moore, Esquire, of
Philadelphia, Mississippi, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and
he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondents in this
case.

MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1971
255
No. 338. Blonder-Tongue Laboratories, Inc., petitioner, v. Uni-
versity of Illinois Foundation et al. The motion of Kawneer Com-
pany, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 507. California Department of Human Resources Develop-
ment et al., appellants, v. Judith Java et al. The motion of The South-
ern California Edison Company, et al., for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amici curiae, is denied. The motion of the State of Ten-
nessee for leave to join in the amicus curiae brief of the State of
New Hampshire is granted. The motion of the State of Illinois for
leave to join in the amicus curiae brief of the State of Maryland is
granted.
No. 853. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Russell L. Wolden.
It having been reported to this Court that Russell L. Wolden, of San
Francisco, State of California, has been disbarred from the practice
of law in all of the Courts of the State of California, and this Court
by order of October 12, 1970, having suspended the said Russell L.
Wolden from the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule
issue requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served
upon the respondent and that the time within which to file a return
to the rule has expired;
It is Ordered that the said Russell L. Wolden be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before
the Bar of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1971
259
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 838. Montana Power Company, petitioner, v. Federal Power
Commission et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Harlan is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted. The
| Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 5987. Jack Kamsler, petitioner, v. Attorney General of United
States. Motion to strike respondent's brief denied. Petition for cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
denied.
No. 5961. Mark Weintraub, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 6043. Neil Keith Rogers, petitioner, v. California. Motion for
leave to amend petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 6028. Rollie L. Shivers, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Director, Division of Corrections of Florida. Motion for leave to
file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 5682. Ernest C. Pickens, petitioner, v. California Supreme
Court. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
No. 6008. Jerry Lynn Young, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that the motion should
be granted.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 5754. Roger R. Dawson and Velma L. Dawson, petitioners, v.
Shenandoah Retreat Land Corporation et al.; and
No. 5768. Franklin D. Calvert, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tions for rehearing denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 25, 1971, until
Monday, February 22, 1971.

substantially all of the opinion.

OPINION
No. 121. Richard Mayberry, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western Dis-
trict. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Western District, for further proceedings in con
en formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Doug-
las. Mr. Justice Black concurs in the judgment and with all the
opinion except that part which indicates that the judge without a
jury could have convicted petitioner of contempt instantaneously
with the outburst. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 434. United Transportation Union, petitioner, v. The State
Bar of Michigan. Argued by Mr. John J. Naughton for the petitioner
and by Mr. A. D. Ruegsegger for the respondent.
No. 133. United States, appellant, v. Thirty-seven (37) Photo-
graphs, Milton Luros, Claimant. Argued by Mr. Solicitor General
Erwin N. Griswold for the appellant and by Mr. Stanley Fleishman
for the appellees.
No. 534. United States, appellant, v. Norman George Reidel.
Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the appellant
and by Mr. Sam Rosenwein for the appellee.

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1971
272
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 6098. Mary Emma Ward et al., appellants, v. Arthur Win-
stead, Commissioner, Public Welfare of Mississippi, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Missis-
sippi. The appeal is dismissed for the reason that the notice of appeal
was not timely filed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2101 (b).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 846. First National City Bank, petitioner, v. Banco Nacional
de Cuba. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari grant-
ed, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
reconsideration in light of the views of the Department of State ex-
pressed in its letter dated November 17, 1970, and transmitted to this
Court by the Solicitor General. In taking this action, the Court is ex-
pressing no views on the merits of the case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The motion of the State of Arizona for leave
to intervene as a party defendant and the motion of the State of In-
diana for leave to intervene as a party plaintiff are referred to the
Special Master.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of
Arkansas. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted.
The defendant is allowed sixty days to answer or otherwise respond
to the complaint.
No. 5338. Robert Apodaca, Harry Morgan Cooper, Jr., and James
Arnold Madden, petitioners, v. Oregon. The motion to dispense with
printing the amicus curiae brief of the National Legal Aid and De-
fender Association is granted.
430-278-71-65

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1971
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
273
No. 759. United States, appellant, v. Armour & Co. and Greyhound
Corporation. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this matter.

to the Supreme Court of Illinois granted.

OPINIONS
No. 65. Kevin L. Donaldson fka Merton H. Sweet, petitioner, v.
United States et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Brennan, believing that under the
facts of this case, petitioner has established no right to intervene,
concurs in the result. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 47. Joseph Charles Usner, petitioner, v. Luckenbach Over-
seas Corporation et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Brennan join. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Harlan.
No. 26. James Edmund Groppi, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Black.
No. 19. United States, appellant, v. Milton C. Jorn. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Utah. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Harlan announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Black
and Mr. Justice Brennan believe that the Court lacks jurisdiction
over this appeal under 18 U.S.C. § 3731 because the action of the trial
judge amounted to an acquittal of appellee and therefore there was no
discretion left to the trial judge to put appellee again in jeopardy.
However, in view of a decision by a majority of the Court to reach
the merits, they join the judgment of the Court. Concurring opinion

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1971
284
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 73. Ida Phillips, petitioner, v. Martin Marietta Corporation.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 97. Ralph Piccirillo, petitioner, v. New York. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Writ of certiorari dis-
missed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice
Black dissents from the dismissal of this writ as improvidently grant-
ed. He would vacate the judgment below and remand the case to the
New York Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of its later
opinion in Matter of Gold v. Menna, 25 N.Y. 2d 475.
Adjourned until Monday, February 22, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, February 22, 1971, will be as follows:
Nos. 5481, 169, 299, and 125.
Х

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1971
285
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDER
It is ordered that the rules, to be known as the Rules of Procedure
for the Trial of Minor Offenses before United States Magistrates, be
and they are prescribed pursuant to § 302(b) of the Federal Magis-
trates Act, which amends § 3402 of Title 18, United States Code. The
rules shall take effect as of the date of this order and supersede the rules
heretofore promulgated by this Court on May 19, 1969. Mr. Justice
Black, with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins, dissents from the Court's
adoption of the rules.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1971

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 734. Edward J. Hegarty, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 915. Mrs. Marion E. Carter, etc., appellant, v. R. E. Harten-
stein dba Hartenstein Elevator Company et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 1002. Gwendolyn Barnard et al., appellants, v. California.
Appeal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of
California, County of Los Angeles. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 921. William B. Richardson, appellant, v. David M. Kennedy,
Secretary of the Treasury, United States Government. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Western District of Penn-
sylvania. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and the case set
for oral argument.
No. 986. George P. Baker et al., appellants, v. Pennsylvania et al
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Pennsylvania. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsyl-
vania with instructions to vacate the interlocutory injunction appealed
from because the injunction, together with the underlying cause, has
become moot.
No. 1003. Tape Industries Association of America et al., appel-
lants, v. Evelle J. Younger, District Attorney, County of Los Angeles,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central
District of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
430-278-71-70

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1971
289
No. 6229. Roy Anderson, appellant, v. New York et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 6047. Frederick J. Christopher, Jr., et al., appellants, v. John
N. Mitchell, Attorney General of the United States, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia for further consideration in light of the
judgment of this Court in No. 43, Orig., Oregon v. Mitchell, No. 44,
Orig., Texas v. Mitchell, No. 46, Orig., U.S. v. Arizona, and No. 47,
Orig., U.S. v. Idaho.

ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit beginning February 1, 1971,
and ending February 4, 1971, and for such further time as may be
required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit during the week of March 22,
1971, and for such further time as may be required to complete unfin-
ished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on
the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

OPINIONS
No. 49. Law Students Civil Rights Research Council, Inc., et al.,
appellants, v. Lowell Wadmond et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Harlan, concurring in this case, and dissenting in Nos. 15 and 18, post.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with whom Mr. Justice
430-278-71-75

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1971
325
Douglas joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 28. Lelia Mae Sanks et al., appellants, v. Georgia et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. Appeal dismissed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan. Mr. Justice Black concurs in the judgment of the
Court dismissing the appeal but does so specifically on the ground
that the case is now moot.
No. 370. Magnesium Casting Company, petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 15. Sara Baird, petitioner, v. State Bar of Arizona. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Mr. Justice Black an-
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which
Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
join. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Arizona for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Harlan dissenting in this case and in No. 18, post, and
concurring in No. 49, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White
in this case and in No. 18, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Harlan,
and Mr. Justice White join.
No. 18. In the Matter of the Application of Martin Robert Stolar,
petitioner. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Mr.
Justice Black announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an
opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr.
Justice Marshall join. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan dissenting in this case and in No. 15,
ante, and concurring in No. 49, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White in this case and in No. 15, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice
Harlan, and Mr. Justice White join.
No. 2. Evelle J. Younger, appellant, v. John Harris, Jr., et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central Dis-
trict of California. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Central District of California
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Concurring opinion by Mr.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1971
326
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Harlan joins in this case and
in Nos. 7, 9, 41, and 83, post. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join concurring
in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in this case and
in No. 4, post.
No. 4. John S. Boyle, Chief Judge of the Circuit Court of Cook
County, Illinois, et al., appellants, v. Lawrence Landry et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of Il-
linois. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Black. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White con-
cur in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in this
case and in No. 2, ante.
No. 7. George Samuels, et al., appellants, v. Thomas J. Mackell,
District Attorney, et al.; and
No. 9. Fred Fernandez, appellant, v. Thomas J. Mackell, District
Attorney, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of New York. Judgments affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Black. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Harlan joins in these cases and in Nos. 2, ante, and 41 and 83, post.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Marshall join, concurring in the result.
No. 60. Leander H. Perez, Jr., et al., appellants, v. August M.
Ledesma, Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment reversed insofar
as it grants injunctive relief. In all other respects the judgment is
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Louisiana with instructions to enter a fresh
decree from which the parties may take an appeal to the United States:
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit if they so desire. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Black. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Black-
mun joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Marshall join, concurring in part and dissenting
in part.
No. 41. Frank Dyson, Chief of Police, City of Dallas, et al., ap-
pellants, v. Brent Stein. Appeal from the United District Court for
the Northern District of Texas. Judgment vacated and case remanded
for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris; and Samuels v.
Mackell, decided this date. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr.

1
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1971
327
Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice Harlan joins in this case and in Nos. 2, 7
and 9, ante, and 83, post. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins concurring in result. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 83. Garrett H. Bryne, etc., et al., appellants, v. Serafim
Karalexis et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Massachusetts. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts
for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris and Samuels v.
Mackell, decided this date. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice Harlan joins in this case and in Nos. 2, 7
and 9, and 41, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

No. 98. Isiah Relford, petitioner, v. Commandant, U.S. Disci-
plinary Barracks, Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 88. George Ramsey and Leon Nunley, dba Leon Nunley Coal
Company, et al., petitioners, v. United Mine Workers of America.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Harlan,
and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 80. Zenith Radio Corporation, petitioner, v. Hazeltine Re-
search, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeal with instructions to reinstate the judgment of
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins concurring in the result.
No. 77. United States, appellant, v. Thomas William Weller. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of California. The Court having no jurisdiction, case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in that Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 62. Monitor Patriot Co., et al., petitioners, v. Roselle A. Roy,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire.

Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New

No. 118, post.

to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further

with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins in this case and in Nos. 62 and

with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas.

No. 5481. Herbert Phillip Schlanger, petitioner, v. Robert C. Sea-

MONDAY, MARCH 1, 19.71
331
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said :
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 787. Bernard J. Ohlendorf et ux., appellants, v. Garnett Gayles
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 929. Marvin J. Morse, appellant, v. D. A. Hindman et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 994. Wilson Burton et al., appellants, v. American National
Bank and Trust Company et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that probable jurisdiction should be noted and the case set for oral
argument.
No. 1026. Sandra Fenton et al., appellants, v. School Committee
of Boston. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
The motion of The National Education Association for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1031. Gerard P. Schneider, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
motion for leave to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement
is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1038. Carol E. Lisker, appellant, v. Joseph J. Kelly, Jr.,
Secretary of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, et al. Appeal from
430-278-71—77

MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1971
332
the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsyl-
vania. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan dissent. Mr. Justice Black is of the opinion that the case
should be dismissed as moot.
No. 1068. George F. Kugler, Jr., in his capacity as Attorney Gen-
eral of New Jersey, et al., appellants, v. Samuel M. Karp et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of New Jersey for further consideration in light
of the judgment of this Court in light of No. 2, Younger v. Harris, No.
7, Samuels v. Mackell, and No. 9, Fernandez v. Mackell. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that judgment should be affirmed for reasons
set forth in his dissenting opinion in No. 2, Younger v. Harris.
No. 1071. Boat Transit, Inc., and Kenosha Auto Transport Corpo-
ration, appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. The
judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice White are of
the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and the case
set for oral argument.
No. 1080. Jim Fair, Individually and as an Elected Official in the
State of Florida, et al., appellants, v. Claude R. Kirk, Jr., as Governor
of the State of Florida, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Florida. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 1096. Harold R. Smith, appellant, v. Eastern Orthodox
Churches of Greater Detroit et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 5946. Earlie Wright, Jr., appellant, v. Mississippi. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and the case
set for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74. Zim Israel Navigation Co., Ltd., petitioner, v. Mario
Tarabocchia. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Usner v. Luckenbach Overseas
Corp., 400 U.S. -, decided January 25, 1971. Mr. Justice Black, Mr.
Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice Brennan dissent.

No. 570. William P. Robinson, Jr., Commissioner of Education
of the State of Rhode Island, et al., appellants, v. John DiCenso et al.
The motion of the National Association of Laymen to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, in No. 89; the motion of the Connecticut State Confer-
ence on Branches of the NAACP et al., for leave to file a brief, amici
curiae, in Nos. 89 and 153; the motion of the Center for Law and Edu-
cation et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in No. 89 out of
time; and the motion of the National Catholic Educational Association
et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in Nos. 569 and 570, are
granted. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun are of the opinion that these motions should be denied be-
cause they were untimely filed. The motion of the Connecticut State
Conference on Branches of the NAACP for leave to file a brief, et al., as
amici curiae, in Nos. 569 and 570; the motion of the Center for Law and
Education et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in Nos. 569
and 570; and the motion of the American Jewish Committee et al., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in Nos. 569 and 570, are granted.
The motion of Peter L. Costas, Esquire, for leave to participate in oral
argument on behalf of the Connecticut State Conference on Branches
of the NAACP et al., as amici curiae, is denied.

No. 835. Robert Kenneth Dewey, petitioner, v. Reynolds Metals
Company. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and thirty minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The respondent is allotted thirty additional
minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that the motion should be
denied. Mr. Justice Harlan took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 982. Robert Y. Eckels, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Delores Ross
et al. The application for stay of modification as required by the

No. 1258. United Aircraft Corporation, petitioner, v. National La-
bor Relations Board. The motion of respondent District 91 to advance
disposition of the petition is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 91. Joseph Arthur Zicarelli, appellant, v. The New Jersey State
Commission of Investigation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted limited to
questions 1, 2, 3, and 4 as set forth in the jurisdictional statement
which read as follows:
"1. Whether a state immunity statute, and in particular N.J.S.A.
52:9M-17, which merely prevents the subsequent use of a witness's

MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1971
335
testimony and evidence derived therefrom is sufficient to supplant
the Fifth Amendment's privilege against self-incrimination?
"2. Whether Counselman v. Hitchcock, 142 U.S. 547 (1892), which
stated that 'absolute immunity against further prosecution' is re-
quired before the Fifth Amendment privilege may be supplanted, is
still the law of the land?
"3. Whether the immunity statute in question, N.J.S.A. 52:9M-17
is constitutionally defective due to its provision that only a 'responsive'
answer, or evidence derived therefrom will not be used against the
witness, where the statute provides no guidelines for determining what
is a 'responsive' answer?
"4. Whether the immunity statute, N.J.S.A. 52:9M-17, can sup-
plant the Fifth Amendment privilege when it fails to provide im-
munity against foreign prosecution, with respect to an individual who
has a real fear of such foreign prosecution?"
As to all other questions set forth in the jurisdictional statement, the
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial Federal question.
Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
this matter.
No. 430. Sally M. Reed, appellant, v. Cecil R. Reed, Administrator,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Idaho. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
No. 769. Buford Ellington, Governor of the State of Tennessee
et al., appellants, v. James F. Blumstein. Appeal from the United

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 565. Albert Sarno and Chris Cardi, petitioners, v. Illinois
Crime Investigating Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Illinois granted limited to questions 1 and 3 as
set forth in the petition which read as follows:
"1. Must the State affirmatively demonstrate to respondents, when
testifying pursuant to the Illinois Immunity Statute, that an im-
munity, as broad in scope as the Fifth Amendment, is available and
applicable to them?
"3. Assuming the immunity statute was not as broad as the Fifth
Amendment, as far as future state prosecutions are concerned, may
a person plead the Fifth Amendment when it is evident, from the im-
plication of the questions in the setting in which they are asked, that
responsive answers to the questions might be dangerous because in-
jurious disclosure could result in future state prosecutions?"

Circuit granted.

Commission et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice
and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.

Railway Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States

part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.

tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

No. 1062. Fields Productions, Inc., petitioner, v. United Artists
Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.

with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, denied.

et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

348
No. 6359. Joel Franklin Levine, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in

No. 6249. Duane Earl Pope, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
to defer consideration of petition denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that the motion should be granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

Warden. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus
denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 6351. Lawrence Eugene Ericksen, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.

cedure, adopted pursuant to Title 28, United States Code, Sections
2072 and 2075 and Title 18, United States Code, Sections 3771 and
3772. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas dissent.

OPINIONS
No. 1066. Citizens to Preserve Overton Park, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. John A. Volpe, Secretary, Department of Transportation,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Black with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 324. Preston A. Tate, petitioner, v. Herman Short, Chief of
Police, Houston, Texas. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal
Appeals of Texas. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr.
Justice Black concurs in the result. Mr. Justice Harlan concurs in the
judgment of the Court on the basis of the considerations set forth in
his opinion concurring in the judgment in Williams v. Illinois, 399
U.S. 235, 259 (1970). Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun, concurring
in the opinion and judgment of the Court.
No. 27. Gladys Boddie et al., appellants, v. Connecticut et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Con-
necticut. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Connecticut for further proceedings

363
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Harlan. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Concurring opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black.
The Clerk, at the direction of the Chief Justice, announced a brief
recess.

MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1971
367
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stew-
art, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 5928. George Washington Durham, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Oregon with directions to dismiss the indictment. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Justice Marshall with whom The Chief Justice and
Mr. Justice Stewart join believes that the case should be dismissed as
moot. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 1115. Magar E. Magar, appellant, v. Maryland. Appeal from
the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1132. City of Millard, Nebraska, et al., appellants, v. City of
Omaha, Nebraska, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Blackmun is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction
should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 1133. D. Reece Williams, III, et al., appellants, v. Robert E.
McNair, Governor of South Carolina, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of South Carolina. The judgment
is affirmed. Mr. Justice Harlan is of the view that the Court lacks
jurisdiction over this direct appeal from a decision of a three-judge
court denying injunctive relief because the state statute attacked was
not one of "general and statewide application". Moody v. Flowers, 387
U.S. 97, 101 (1967). Therefore, he would vacate the judgment of the
430-278-71—84

MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1971
368
District Court and remand the case to that court so that it might enter
a fresh decree from which timely appeal could be taken to the Court
of Appeals. See Rockefeller v. Catholic Medical Center, 397 U.S. 820
(1970).
No. 1151. In the Matter of Richard A. Napolitano, appellant. Ap-
peal from the Illinois Courts Commission. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan would
dismiss appeal for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 6394. Carl K. Yeto, petitioner, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in light of
Johnson v. United States, 352 U.S. 565.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Spencer Haywood, petitioner, v. Charles M. Merrill
et al. The motion of the National Basketball Association to vacate
the stay heretofore granted by Mr. Justice Douglas is denied. Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that the
motion to vacate should be granted.
No.. John Michael Galasso, petitioner, v. Commanding Officer,
Ft. Hamilton, et al. The application for a stay of the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and for release
on bail is denied.
No. 91. Joseph Arthur Zicarelli, appellant, v. The New Jersey
State Commission of Investigation. The application for release on
bail is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinon that the applica-
tion should be granted. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
No. 712. Triangle Improvement Council et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam S. Ritchie, Commissioner, State Road Commission of West Vir-
ginia, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to permit
William Bradford Reynolds to present oral argument, pro hac vice,
is granted.
No. 1341. Jesse L. Jackson et al., appellants, v. Richard Ogilvie,
Governor of the State of Illinois, et al. The motion to expedite con-
sideration of the appeal is denied.
No. 1363. Gerardo Catena, appellant, v. New Jersey State Com-
mission of Investigation. The motion to expedite consideration of the

MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1971
369
appeal is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 1386. The Chicago Housing Authority et al., petitioners, v.
Dorothy Gautreaux et al. The application for a stay presented to Mr.
Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 1390. Johnnie Pruett, appellant, v. Texas. The application for
a stay of the mandate presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 1129. Oliver T. Fein, petitioner, v. Selective Service System
Local Board No. 7, Yonkers, N. Y., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 5940. Francis Haines, petitioner, v. Otto J. Kerner, Former
Governor, State of Illinois, et al. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 6048. John Adams, petitioner, v. Illinois. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Illinois granted limited to question 2 as set forth in
the petition which reads as follows:
"2. Whether Coleman v. Alabama, 399 U.S. 1 (1970) is retroactive
and/or applicable to a cause where, prior to trial, the defendant ob-
jected to the failure to provide counsel at the preliminary hearing?”
CERTIORARI DENIED

No. 1211. Travis Levy, petitioner, v. United States. Petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

took no part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.

MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1971
375
No. 6429. Freda Epling, etc., petitioner, v. M. T. Epling Com-
pany. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

No. 1121. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, et al., pe-
titioners, v. Vulcan Materials Company. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 1126. Peter S. Sarelas, petitioner, v. Board of Managers &
Committee on Grievances of the Chicago Bar Ass'n, as Comm'rs of the
Supreme Court of Illinois. Motion to dispense with printing petition

nois denied.
No. 1146. Saul Stambler et al., petitioners, v. John J. Dillon et al.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied.
No. 1138. Robert Gregory Mickey et al., petitioners, v. California.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of
California, County of Los Angeles, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1148. Kenneth F. Howard, petitioner, v. American Mail Line,
Ltd. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon
denied. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas, and Mr. Justice Bren-
nan are of the opinion that the judgment should be reversed. Rogers v.
Missouri Pacific Railroad Co., 352 U.S. 500.
No. 5115. Roger Labatt, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 5693. Lee I. Johnson, petitioner, v. New York. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall are of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 5497. Gerald Lee Brown, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.

OPINIONS
No. 85. Guy Porter Gillette, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit; and
No. 325. Louis A. Negre, petitioner, v. Stanley R. Larsen et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Mr. Justice Black concurs in the Court's judgment and in Part I of
the opinion of the Court. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in
No. 85. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in No. 325.
No. 124. Willie S. Griggs et al., petitioners, v. Duke Power Com-
pany. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr.
Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 63. Grove Press, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Maryland State
Board of Censors. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Judgment affirmed by an equally divided court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 573. Reubin Askew et al., appellants, v. Robert H. Hargrave
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida for
further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Black
concurs in the judgment and Part II of the opinion.
Adjourned until Monday, March 22, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, March 22, 1971, will be as follows: Nos.
600, 609, 727, 712, and 655.
Х

MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1971
387
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 1059. United Mine Workers of America, petitioner, v. Chester
Railing and Paul Railing dba C&P Coal Company. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of Zenith Radio Corp. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc. 401 U.S.-
(1970). Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Har-
lan would grant the petition and set case for oral argument on the
merits.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 423. Electronic Industries Association, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or discussion of this case.
No. 877. Juliette Bernier, Mother, on behalf of Theodore Bernier,
Jr., appellant, v. Maine et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial
Cout of Maine. The motion to dispense with printing the jurisdic-
tional statement is granted. The appeal is dismissed as moot.
No. 882. Sallie M. Hadnott et al., appellants, v. Mabel S. Amos,
Secretary of State of Alabama, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. The motion to
dispense with printing the jurisdictional statement and for other re-
lief is granted. The motion of appellee Hildreth to dispense with print-
ing motion to affirm is granted. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted
and case set for oral argument.
No. 1168. Klatex, Inc., appellant, v. Ashton J. Mouton, Collector of
Revenue, State of Louisiana. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
430-278-71- -87

MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1971
388
eral question. Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the
opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for
oral argument.
No. 1187. Katherine Smythe Masters, appellant, v. Executor,
Heirs, Legatees, Devisees, Distributors of the Estate of Paul H.
Smythe, Jr., etc. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Sec-
ond District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1190. The National Life and Accident Insurance Company,
appellant v. Barbara D. Notter. Appeal from the Court of Civil Ap-
peals of Texas, Tenth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 6144. Glenwood Sylvester Quinn, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 6457. Roy Anderson et ux., appellants, v. Secretary of the
Treasury et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 6476. Willie Ford and Arnold McClellan, appellants, v. Cali-
fornia. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1215. New Orleans Book Mart, Inc., et al., appellants. v. John
N. Mitchell, Attorney General of the U.S., et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida. The
judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that prob-
able jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 1218. Joan Hayes, appellant, v. The Lieutenant Governor of
the State of Hawaii. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The
appeal is dismissed as moot.
No. 1225. Reptile Products Association, Inc., appellant, v. Henry
A. Diamond, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion.

MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1971
389
No. 6559. Leola Johnson et al., appellants, v. Paul N. Marston et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Arizona. The judgment is affirmed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. James Buckley et al., appellants, v. Rita Johnson et al.
The application for a stay of the order of the United States District
Court for the District of Connecticut entered in Civil Action No.
13432 on November 20, 1970, which application was presented to Mr.
Justice Harlan, and by him referred to the Court, is granted, and the
said order is hereby stayed pending the timely filing of an appeal in
this Court. Should the appeal be so timely filed, the stay will remain
in effect pending its disposition. In the event the appeal is dismissed,
the stay is to terminate automatically. Should jurisdiction be noted
or postponed, the stay is to remain in effect pending the issuance of the
judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas and
Mr. Justice Harlan are of the opinion that stay should be denied. The
motion of Rita Johnson et al. to expedite the appeal is denied.
No.. Jane Doe and Sally Roe etc., appellants, v. William J.
Scott, Attorney General, et al. The motion to shorten the time to
docket appeal is denied.
No. James William Donofrio, appellant, v. United States.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Black, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. Bennie G. Thompson, petitioner, v. Selective Service
System Local Board No. 28, et al. The application for stay of induction
presented to Mr. Justice Black, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the opin-
ion that the stay should be granted.
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. The
Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral argu-
ment in due course. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this matter.
No. 362. Vincent Francis McGee, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of Richard K. LeGrande for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The motion for authorization for the payment
of counsel for preparation of the brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 409. The Board of Education of the Little Rock School Dis-
trict et al., petitioners, v. Dolores Clark et al. The application for a
stay restraining the petitioners from continuing any construction
at Henderson Junior High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, pending
final disposition of all issues presented in case No. 20485 now pending
before the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit,

MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1971
390
which application was presented to Mr. Justice Black, and by him
referred to the Court, is granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 557. United States, appellant, v. International Minerals &
Chemical Corporation. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave
for John F. Dienelt to present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 1081. Edgar D. Whitcomb, Governor of Indiana, etc., et al.,
appellants, v. Don Affeldt et al. The application for a stay of judg-
ment of the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Indiana presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. 5586. Paul J. Bell, Jr., petitioner, v. R. H. Burson, Director,
Georgia Department of Public Safety. The motion of Elizabeth Roed-
iger Rindskopf for leave to argue pro hac vice on behalf of petitioner
is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 1232. Richard L. Roudebush, appellant, v. R. Vance Hartke
et al.; and
No. 1236. Theodore L. Sendak, Attorney General of Indiana, ap-
pellant, v. R. Vance Hartke et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Indiana. Further con-
sideration of the question of jurisdiction in these cases postponed to
the hearing of the cases on the merits. Cases consolidated and a total
of one hour allowed for oral argument.

No. 1134. Gregory Paul Noonan, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 1163. Stephen Dash et al., petitioners, v. The Commanding
General, Fort Jackson, South Carolina, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 1179. Charles Sellers et al., petitioners, v. The Regents of the
University of California. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1186. Mescalero Apache Tribe et al., petitioners, v. Fred J.
Russell, Acting Secretary of the Interior. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

yard, a Division of Hunt Tool Company, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.

Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

exhausted.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 29, 1971, until
Monday, April 5, 1971.
