MONDAY. MARCH 22, 1971
The Chief Justice said:
414
"Before we hear arguments in the first case today I have a pleasant
task, if it can be called that. This is the nearest sitting of the Court
to Friday, the 19th of March, and that is an important day because
it marked the 80th birthday of the very distinguished former Chief
Justice of the United States, Earl Warren.
"This is another milestone in his great career of public service which
extends over a period of more than a half century. Chief Justice
Warren presided over this Court for a few months short of 16 years
and in one the most important periods in the history of the Court
and the country.
"I know that I speak for every one of my colleagues on the bench
and for Mr. Justice Reed and Mr. Justice Clark, retired, when I say
for the record, and to you, sir, Chief Justice Warren, that we wish you
the best of everything in the years ahead and many, many more years
of the vigorous good health which you have always enjoyed and our
very best wishes to you and to Mrs. Warren on the occasion of your
80th birthday."
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 600. Alcides Perez, petitioner, v. United States. Argued by Mr.
Albert J. Krieger for the petitioner and by Mr. Solicitor General
Erwin N. Griswold for the respondent.
No. 609. John O. Graham, Commissioner, Department of Public
Welfare, State of Arizona, appellant, v. Carmen Richardson, etc.
Argued by Mr. Michael F. Flam for the appellant and by Mr. Anthony
B. Ching for the appellee.
No. 727. William P. Sailer et al., appellants, v. Elsie Mary Jane
Leger and Beryl Jervis. Leave granted Mr. Jonathan M. Stein to ap-
pear and present oral argument for the appellees, pro hac vice, on mo-
tion of Mr. Joseph P. Work. Argued by Mr. Joseph P. Work for the
appellants and Mr. Jonathan M. Stein for the appellees, pro hac vice,
by special leave of Court.
No. 712. Triangle Improvement Council et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam S. Ritchie, Commissioner, State Road of Commission of West
Virginia, et al. Argued by Mr. Jack Greenberg for the petitioners, by
Mr. William Bradford Reynolds for the Federal respondents, pro
hac vice, by special of Court, and by Mr. Stanley E. Preiser for the
State respondents. Lave

OPINIONS
No. 5481. Herbert Phillip Schlanger, petitioner, v. Robert C.
Seamans, Jr., Secretary of the Air Force, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Harlan
concurs in the result. Mr. Justice Stewart dissents.
No. 41, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Wyandotte Chemicals
Corporation et al. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint. Motion
for leave to file a bill of complaint denied without prejudice to its
right to commence other appropriate judicial proceedings. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

tice Burger, Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Stewart join.

to the Supreme Court of Colorado. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by

in this case and in No. 812, post.

for Water Division No. 5, State of Colorado, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Colorado. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by

this case and in No. 87, ante.

the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment affirmed by an equally
divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
420
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stew-
art, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Black-
mun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 31. Charlie Cato et al., appellants, v. Georgia et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. The judgment is affirmed. Stefanelli v. Minard, 342 U.S. 117,
and Perez v. Ledesma. 401 U.S. 82, decided February 23, 1971. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted.
No. 43. Robert L. Shevin et al., appellants, v. Matthew B. Lazarus.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Florida. The motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District for the Southern District of Florida for reconsidera-
tion in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided February
23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and
affirm judgment.
No. 90. James E. Barlow et al., appellants, v. Edward Gallant et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Texas. The motion of appellees Morris and Walters for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Western District
of Texas for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S.
37, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas would note prob-
able jurisdiction and affirm judgment.
No. 102. J. C. Goodman, Jr., as Chief of Police of Charlotte,
North Carolina, et al., appellants, v. Mrs. Raymond M. Wheeler, next
friend, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of North Carolina. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Western District
of North Carolina for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris,
430-278-71- -93

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
421
401 U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and affirm judgment.
No. 112. Ann Marie LeClair et al., appellants, v. George D. O'Neil,
Chief of Police of the City of Worcester, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The judgment
is affirmed. Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided February 23,
1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S.
66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
,
No. 217. Johnnie Reb's Book and Card Shop et al., appellants, v.
Lewis R. Slaton, District Attorney, Atlanta Judicial Circuit, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Georgia. The judgment is affirmed. Younger v. Harris, 401
U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fer-
nandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice
Douglas dissents from the affirmance.
No. 5462. Harold A. Porter, appellant, v. Herbert B. Kimzey, Dis-
trict Attorney, Mountain Circuit, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. The judgment is
affirmed. Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971;
and Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66 decided
February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the affirmance.
No. 5952. Hugh S. Geiger, Jr., appellant, v. B. H. Jenkins, Presi-
dent of State Board of Medical Examiners of Georgia, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. The judgment is affirmed. Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37,
decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez
v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971.
No. 116. Irene McGrew et al., appellants, v. City of Jackson, Mis-
sissippi, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Mississippi for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401
U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and
Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 134. James Ira Hosey et al., appellants, v. City of Jackson,
Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Mississippi for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401
TTS. 37. decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and
Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr.

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
422
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 844. ABC Books, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Thomas D. Benson,
Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Tennessee, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Middle District of
Tennessee. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee for reconsidera-
tion in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided Febru-
ary 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401
U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for
oral argument.
No. 5164. Waldron Hayne Dyches, Jr., appellant, v. Andrew J.
Ryan, Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Georgia. Motion of appellant for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remand-
ed to the United States District Court for the Southern District of
Georgia for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 US.
37, decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and
Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 236. Phil Campbell, Commissioner of Agriculture of the
State of Georgia, et al., appellants, v. Tom Lewis. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The judgment
is affirmed. Campbell v. Hussey, 368 U.S. 297. Mr. Justice Black and
Mr. Justice Harlan are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction
should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 289. Henry Wade, etc., appellant, v. Alvin Leon Buchanan
et al.; and
No. 290. Alvin Leon Buchanan and Travis Lee Strickland, ap-
pellants, v. Henry Wade, etc. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Texas. Motion of the North Amer-
ican Conference of Hemophile Organizations for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, in No. 290, granted. Judgment vacated and cases re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Texas for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S.
37, decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fern-
andez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that No. 289 should be dismissed as untimely
filed and that probable jurisdiction should be noted in No. 290.

Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
423
Massachusetts. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts to consider the

No. 888. Board of Public Instruction of Dade County, appellant,
v. Andrew Robert Banks. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Florida so that a fresh decree may be entered from which a timely
appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit if the appellant so chooses.
No. 1250. Lynn G. Starns and Linda J. Mack, appellants, v. Les-
ter A. Malkerson et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Minnesota. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice
White is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted
and case set for oral argument.

et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. The judgment is affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case
set for oral argument.
No. 1275. Oriental Boulevard Company et al., appellants, v.
Austin Heller, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 1282. Martin S. Malinou, appellant, v. Board of Elections of
Rhode Island et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 1284. Alexander G. Balc, appellant, v. Adam Parsons et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. Motion to dispense with
printing jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 5013. James Rollins et al., appellants, v. Thomas W. Shannon.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Missouri. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri for recon-
sideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided Feb-
ruary 23, 1971; Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S.
66, decided February 23, 1971; and Boyle v. Landry, 401 U.S. 77,
decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas concurs on the basis
of his separate opinion in Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v.
Mackell.

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
424
No. 5412. Wilbert Montell Brown, appellant, v. S. M. Fallis, Dis-
trict Attorney for Tulsa County, Oklahoma, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.

granted. Judgment affirmed, Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided

Industrial Commissioner. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-

CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
-
No. 20. Alfred W. Wright et al., petitioners, v. City of Montgom-
ery, Alabama, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for reconsideration in light of Younger v. Harris, 401
U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971; and Samuels v. Mackell and Fer-
nandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided February 23, 1971. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted and
judgment reversed.
No. 500. John J. Ferdon et al., petitioners, v. Demich, Inc., et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
reconstruction in light of Perez v. Ledesma, 401 U.S. 82, decided
February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that judgment
should be affirmed.
No. 5539. Elroy Embry et al., petitioners, v. Ivan Allen, Jr., etc.,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioners for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed. Case remanded to the Court of Appeals,
Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, decided February 23, 1971; and
Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided
February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun are
of the opinion that certiorari should be granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded for reconsideration in light of the above cited
cases.

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
425
No.- Stephen L. Gregory et al., petitioners, v. Curtis W. Tarr,
National Director of the Selective Service System, et al. The applica-
tion for recall of the mandate and stay of the mandate of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit heretofore granted by
Mr. Justice Stewart pending further order of the Court, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would extend
the stay granted by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 1028. United States, petitioner, v. Dimas Campos-Serrano.
The motions of the respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and for the appointment of counsel are granted and it is ordered that
John J. Cleary, Esquire, of Chicago, Illinois, a member of the Bar of
this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
No. 1184. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Plaster-
ers' Local Union No. 79, etc., et al.; and
No. 1231. Texas State Tile & Terrazzo Co., Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Plasterers' Local Union No. 79, etc., et al. The motion of the Labor-
ers' International Union of North America, AFL-CIO, for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 1184, granted. The motion of the
Associated General Contractors of America et al., for leave to file a
brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 1262. George K. Wyman et al., appellants, v. Catherine Boddie
et al.;
No. 1269. Harold O. Swank, Director, Illinois Department of Pub-
lic Aid, appellant, v. Gladys Rodriquez et al.; and
No. 6553. Ruth J. Jefferson et al., appellants, v. Burton G. Hackney
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in each of these
cases expressing the views of the United States.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 127. D. H. Overmyer Co., Inc. of Ohio, et al., petitioners, v.
Frick Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of Ohio, Lucas County, granted.
No. 1183. Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, AFL-CIO,
petitioner, v. Prepmore Apparel, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted.
No. 1278. Federal Trade Commission, petitioner, v. The Sperry
and Hutchinson Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 1285. United States, petitioner, v. Denneth Bass. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit granted.
No. 6046. Don Richard Lego, petitioner, v. John Twomey, Warden.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to question 1 as set forth in
the petition which read as follows:
"1. Was the Illinois evidentiary rule for determining the volun-
tariness of extra-judicial confessions so highly unreliable as to contra-
vene the Appellant's Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights and,
necessarily, deprive the Appellant of the Fifth Amendments right
against self-incrimination because:
"(a) The trial judge in his preliminary determination, removed
from the jury, need not find the confession voluntary beyond reason-
able doubt when judging its admissibility as evidence for the jury;
and,
"(b) The defendant, as a matter of Illinois law, was precluded
from having the jury instructed upon, and to determine the volun-
tariness of the confession along with the other factual issues upon
which the jury verdict must rest?"

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971

OPINIONS
No. 136. Harold Whiteley, petitioner, v. Warden of Wyoming State
Penitentiary. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with directions that the writ is to issue unless
the state makes appropriate arrangements to retry petitioner. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Blackmun agrees
with much that is said by Mr. Justice Black and also dissents from
the opinion and judgment of this Court.
No. 5257. Lou Bertha Labine, natural tutrix of minor child, Rita
Nell Vincent, appellant, v. Wilbur Vincent, Administrator of the

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1971
440
succession of Ezra Vincent. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisi-
ana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White, and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, April 5, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
☑

.
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
441
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 6131. James Melvin Kitchens, petitioner, v. S. Lamont Smith,
Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Georgia. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 422. United States, appellant, v. James Francis McFadden.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of California. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California for re-
consideration in light of Gillette v. United States, and Negre v. Larsen,
401 U.S., decided March 8, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 1229. Shipyard Drive-In Theatre, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Joseph Scuncio et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the
opinion that the judgment be reversed.
No. 1252. Earl H. Pratz, Sr., et al., appellants, v. Louisiana Poly-
technic Institute et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the
opinion that the question of jurisdiction should be postponed to a
hearing of the case on the merits and case set for oral argument.
No. 1313. Hollis Berry, Jr., appellant, v. Aetna Casualty & Surety
Company et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Louisiana, Sec-
ond Circuit. The motion of Arthur Cobb and the Louisiana Trial
430-278-71-
-96

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
442
Lawyers Association for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set
for oral argument.
No. 1323. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Com-
pany et al., appellants, v. Apache County et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Arizona. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Black is of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 1326. Preston Smith, Governor of the State of Texas, et al.,
appellants, v. Anita S. Garza et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of Texas. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of Texas so that the District Court may enter a fresh judg-
ment from which a timely appeal may be taken to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit if the appellants so choose.
'Gunn v. University Committee to End the War in Vietnam, et al., 399
U.S. 383 (1970). Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the judg-
ment should be affirmed, being of the view that the appeal is properly
before this Court.
No. 1330. The Huntington National Bank of Columbus, appellant,
v. Robert J. Kosydar, Tax Commissioner of Ohio. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 56. Cleo Epps, petitioner, v. United States. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Oklahoma with directions to dismiss the indictment.
Durham v. United States, 401 U.S. -, decided March 8, 1971. The
Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun are of the opinion that the motion of counsel for the re-
spondent to dismiss the petition as moot should be granted. See the
dissenting opinions in Durham v. United States, supra.
No. 72. United States, petitioner, v. Thomas Henry Shields. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for recon-

-
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
443
sideration in light of Gillette v. United States, and Negre v. Larsen,
401 U.S. decided March 8, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 786. Harold G. Childs, petitioner, v. Oregon et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted and judgment re-
versed. Redrup v. New York, 386 U.S. 767 (1967). The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that
certiorari should be denied.
No. 976. Donald Somerville, petitioner, v. Illinois. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light
of United States v. Jorn, 400 U.S. 470; and Downums v. United States,
372 U.S. 734 (1963). Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the
petition should be granted and judgment reversed. United States v.
Jorn, 400 U.S. 470.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 712. Triangle Improvement Council et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam S. Ritchie, Commissioner, State Road Commission of West Vir-
ginia, et al. The motion for leave to file petitioner's reply brief out of
time is granted.
No. 824. M.F.A. Central Cooperative et al., petitioners, v. Edwin
O. Bookwalter, District Director of Internal Revenue, et al. The
motion to expedite consideration of petition for certiorari is denied.
The motion of petitioner to argue orally, as amicus curiae, in No. 1082
is denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of these motions.
No. 1395. Carmine G. DeSapio, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to examine sealed briefs filed on behalf
of respondent in No. 825, Oct. Term, 1970, is granted. Mr. Justice
White took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 5940. Francis Haines, petitioner, v. Otto J. Kerner, Former
Governor, State of Illinois, et al. The motion of petitioner for the ap-
pointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Stanley A. Bass,
Esquire, of New York, New York, a member of the Bar of this Court,
be, and he is hereby appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in
this case.
No. 6400. Walter Rodger Webster et al., petitioners, v. United
States. The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Black, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.

for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
448
No. 12. J. D. Cox, Superintendent, Virginia State Penitentiary, pe-
titioner, v. Thomas Edward McLaren. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would dismiss the petition as moot.
No. 45. Don Bertram Pratt, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.
No. 1000. Scudder & German, petitioner, v. Stanley S. Pearlstein.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Doug-
las, and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.
No. 1243. Leo Tom Hopkins, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied.
No. 1297. Board of Education of Netcong, New Jersey, et al., pe-
titioners, v. State Board of Education et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 1300. Eleanor V. Curtin, as Administratrix of the Estate of
George F. Gibson, etc., deceased, petitioner, v. Superior Court of
California, in and for the County of Alameda. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Apellate District,
denied. Mr. Justice Black is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.
No. 1321. Bryan Jerome Maker, petitioner, v. Wisconsin. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice Marshall are of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted and judgment reversed.
Thompson v. Louisville, 362 U.S. 199 (1960).
No. 5311. Robert Thomas Moore, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted. Mr. Justice Harlan is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for recon-

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
449
decided
sideration in light of his opinion in Welsh v. United States, 398 U.S.
333 (1970), and Gillette v. United States, 401 U.S.
March 8, 1971.
No. 5722. Joseph Michael Compton, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.
No. 6224. Eugene R. Haffke, petitioner, v. California. Motion to
strike exhibits submitted by respondent denied. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict, denied.
No. 6272. Leon Smith, petitioner, v. Lackland Bloom, Judge of
the Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Missouri denied. Mr. Justice Black and
Mr. Justice Douglas are of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.
No. 6491. Stephen Luther Evans, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 6515. Stanley Meadows, Michael Henley and Waverly E. Fu-
trell, petitioners, v. United States Marshal, Northern District of Geor-
gia. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Stewart are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 6307. Albert Aduna Frias, petitioner, v. L. S. Nelson, Warden.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 1274. Robert V. Rafter, petitioner, v. Austin Hoyt, Judge of
the United States Tax Court. Motion for leave to file petition for writ
of mandamus denied.

The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, April 19, 1971.

OPINIONS
No. 24. William P. Rogers, Secretary of State, appellant, v. Aldo
Mario Bellei. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 5342. James Wintfored Rewis and Mary Lee Williams, peti-
tioners, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgments reversed and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice White took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 81. Clarence Williams, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 82. Joseph Elkanich, petitioner, v. United States. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgments affirmed. Mr. Justice White announced the judgment of the
Court and an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice
Stewart, and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. While joining the opinion of
the Court, Mr. Justice Stewart would also affirm the judgment in No.
82 on the alternative ground that the issue presented is not one cogniza-
ble in a proceeding brought under 28 U.S.C. § 2255. See Harris v.

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
459
Nelson, 394 U.S. 286, 307 (dissenting opinion); Kaufman v. United
States, 394 U.S. 217, 242 (dissenting opinion); Chambers v. Maroney,
399 U.S. 42, 54 (concurring opinion). Mr. Justice Black, while adher-
ing to his opinion in Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U.S. 618 (1965), con-
curs in the result on the ground that he believes that Chimel v. Cali-
fornia, 395 U.S. 752 (1969), was wrongly decided. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan concurring
in No. 36, post and in No. 82, and dissenting in No. 81. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and dissenting in part. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
No. 36. Fred T. Mackey, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice White announced the judg-
ment of the Court and an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan concurring in this case and in No. 82, ante, and dis-
senting in No. 81, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall joins concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Black joins.
No. 13. United States, petitioner, v. James A. White. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court.
Mr. Justice White announced the judgment of the Court and an opin-
ion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join. Mr. Justice Black, while adhering to his views
expressed in Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U.S. 618, 640 (1965), concurs
in the judgment of the Court for the reasons set forth in his dissent in
Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 364 (1967). Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 51. Archie William Hill, Jr., petitioner, v. California. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice Black concurs in the result.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 61. Investment Company Institute et al., petitioners, v. Wil-
liam B. Camp, Comptroller of the Currency, et al.; and
No. 59. National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., petitioner,
v. Securities and Exchange Commission et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1971
460
cuit. Judgment in No. 61 reversed and vacated in No. 59 and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Chief Justice Burger took no part in
the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 5. United States, petitioner, v. United States Coin and Cur-
rency, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan. Mr. Justice Black concurs in the Court's judgment
and the opinion so as it goes. He would go further and now overrule
Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U.S. 618 (1965), and its progeny. Concur-
ring opinion by Mr. Justice Bernnan. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Ste-
wart and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 345. United States, appellant, v. Donald Freed and Shirley
Jean Sutherland. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Central District of California. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Central District
of California for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan concurring in the judgment of reversal.
No. 434. United Transportation Union, petitioner, v. The State
Bar of Michigan. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michi-
gan. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Michigan for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Opinion by Mr. Justice Har-
lan concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the decision
of this case.
No. 5247. Barrington Joseph Johnson, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as
improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Justice
Black. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Douglas joins. Mr. Chief Justice Burger took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, April 19, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, April 19, 1971, will be as follows: Nos.
783, 577, 821, 759, and 840.

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1971
461
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Ste-
wart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 1347. Fairview Development, Inc., appellant, v. City of Fair-
banks. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 1368. Harold C. Foreman, appellant, v. City of Bellefontaine,
Ohio, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Logan County.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 1426. Benjamin T. Delahay, Jr., appellant, v. Alaska et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari, is denied.
No. 6381. Walter Price, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 1352. Consolidated Carriers Corp., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1353. E. Michael McCann, appellant, v. Sidney G. Babbitz.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Wisconsin. Judgement vacated and case remanded to the United
430-278-71-99

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1971
462
States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin in light
of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971); and Samuels v. Mackell and
Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66 (1971). Mr. Justice Douglas dis-
sents from the remand.
No. 1367. Clairol, Incorporated, appellant, v. Director, Division
of Taxation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Motion
of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, Inc., for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Harlan is of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 1390. Johnnie Pruett, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from the
Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 1391. H. L. Federman & Company, Inc., appellant, v. John
A. Zerbel, dba John A. Zerbel & Company. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 1428. Bernard Allen Fried et al., appellants, v. Matthew
Danaher, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 962. Richard John Kostamo, appellant, v. Northern City Na-
tional Bank et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan dissent from the dismissal
of the appeal.
No. 5925. Dorothy Jeanette Hietala, appellant, v. The Heir of
Peter Pakarinen. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan dissent from the dismissal
of the appeal. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 5029. Donald Romontio, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 538. Nellie Swarb et al., appellants, v. William M. Lennox
et al. The motion to proceed on the original record and the motion to
dispense wth printing appellants' brief on the merits are granted.

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1971
463
No. 798. United States et al., petitioners, v. Anne Goyne Mitchell
et al. The motion of respondent Angello for additional time for oral
argument granted and an additional fifteen minutes is allotted for
that purpose. The Solicitor General is also granted an additional fif-
teen minutes to argue on behalf of the United States.
No. 835. Robert Kenneth Dewey, petitioner, v. Reynolds Metals
Company. The motion of the National Jewish Commission on Law
and Public Affairs et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is
granted. The motion of the Chamber of Commerce of the United
States; and the motion of the American Jewish Congress for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, are granted. Mr. Justice Harlan took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 1042. Florence Diffenderfer and Nishan Paul, appellants, v.
Central Baptist Church of Miami, Florida, Incorporated, et al. The
joint motion to dispense with printing the appendix record is granted.
No. 1463. Dekar Industries, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Bissett-
Berman Corporation. The motion of the respondent to restrict dis-
tribution of the petition or in the alternative to delete portions thereof
is denied.

peal from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Illinois. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

for the Second Circuit denied.

for the Fourth Circuit denied.

States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.

denied.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Connecticut denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas
denied.

rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Edward Stanley Miller and Joseph T.
Quinones. Motion of respondent Miller for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.

No. 1315. Margaret Loretta Nolte, petitioner, v. United States.

writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied.

Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied.

dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of certio-

denied.

472
No. 1281. Eerik Heine, petitioner, v. Juri Raus. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Stewart are of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1310. Lee Edwards, petitioner, v. Lem C. Bryan, Receiver for
Arkansas Loan and Thrift Corporation, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
No. 6635. Harry R. Smith, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 1316. 2,608.84 Acres of Land in Tarrant County, Texas, et al.,
petitioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Black
joins.
No. 1340. Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization et al.,
petitioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. The
Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice White are of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1350. United Transportation Union, petitioner, v. Illinois
Central Railroad Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.
No. 1351. Interboro Contractors, Inc., petitioner, v. National Labor
Relations Board. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White is
of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1356. Joseph V. Franco, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 1359. Lester Wheeler, petitioner. v. Lykes Bros. Steamship
Co., Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

Dorothy Gautreaux et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1971
473
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1432. Staughton Lynd et al., petitioners, v. City of Chicago.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.
No. 6087. Lawrence Harper McKenzie, petitioner, v. Director,
Patuxent Institution, Maryland. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 6567. Claud Michael Kember, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 1376. Samuel Goldwyn Productions et al., petitioners, v. James
A. Mulvey. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 6082. Bobbie Harrington and Marcie Harrington, petitioners,
v. California. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
California denied. Mr. Justice Harlan would grant certiorari, vacate
judgment below and remand case in light of Chimel v. California. 395
U.S. 752 (1969) and his separate opinion in Williams v. United States
(and companion cases), 401 U.S. —, — (1971).
No. 6484. Benny Saldana Aguirre, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sec-
ond Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Harlan would grant
certiorari, vacate judgment below and remand case in light of Chimel
v. California, 395 U.S. 752 (1969) and his separate opinion in Wil-
liams v. United States (and companion cases, 401 U.S.
(1971).
No. 6105. Albert Lonzo Cantrell, petitioner, v. R. J. Gaffney, War-
den. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied and;
No. 6512. Albert Lonzo Cantrell, petitioner, v. Kansas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas denied. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of these
petitions.
No. 6325. Gerald Stanley Nemke, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied. Mr. Justice
Harlan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari, vacate judg-
ment below and remand case in light of Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S.

478 (1964); Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966); and their sepa-

(1971).

writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.

den, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit beginning June 1, 1971, and ending
June 4, 1971, and for such further time as may be required to complete
unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 26, 1971, until
Monday, May 3, 1971.

ORDER
No. Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, peti-
tioner, v. A Quaker Action Group et al. Upon consideration of the ap-
plication of the Solicitor General of the United States for a stay
herein and the opposition to such stay on behalf of the respondents
presented to the Chief Justice as Circuit Justice for the District of
Columbia Circuit at 6:00 p.m. on April 20, 1971, the Chief Justice
entered an order dated April 20, 1971, vacating the order of the United
States Court of Appeals, dated April 19, 1971, which modified the

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 21, 1971
493
preliminary injunction issued on April 16, 1971, by the United States
District Court for the District of Columbia and reinstated the said
order of the District Court dated April 16, 1971, pending further order
of the Court; and said matter being referred by the Chief Justice to
the Court and the Court having consideerd the matter,
It is ordered
(1) that the Order of the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit dated April 19, 1971, modifying the
preliminary injunction issued by the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia on April 16, 1971, is vacated;
(2) that the preliminary injunction issued by the United States Dis-
trict Court herein on April 16, 1971, is reinstated with full force and
effect. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration of this
matter.
Adjourned until Monday, April 26, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, April 26, 1971, will be as follows: Nos.
758, 557, and 31 Original.
×

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1971
494
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM
No.
-
Wilfred Keyes, petitioner, v. School District Number
One, Denver, Colorado. The sole basis for the Tenth Circuit's action
in granting the stay of the District Court's order in this case was the
view "that it would be unfair to the School District to compel it to
take further steps in the implementation of the total plan until (the
Tenth Circuit) and the party litigants have the benefit of the United
States Supreme Court decisions in the Swann and combined desegre-
gation cases. . .”
The decisions in those cases having now been announced, it is proper
to vacate the stay and remit the matter to the Court of Appeals freed
of its earlier speculation as to the bearing of our decision in the Swann
cases.
We, of course, intimate no views upon the merits of the underlying
issues.
Mr. Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of
this matter.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 48. Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of
Arkansas.
It is ordered that the Honorable Clifford O'Sullivan, Senior Circuit
Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit,
be, and he is hereby, appointed Special Master in this case. The
Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions
for filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings,
and authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such
evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it necessary
to call for. The master is directed to submit such reports as he may
deem appropriate.
430-278-71—105

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1971
495
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court hereafter may approve.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
No. 1285. United States, petitioner, v. Denneth Bass. The motion
of respondent for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is
ordered that William E. Hellerstein, Esquire, of New York, New
York, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 1395. Carmine G. DeSapio, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to copy briefs for respondent in No.
825, October Term, 1970, is granted. Mr. Justice White took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 5515. Donald Gilbert Humphrey, petitioner, v. Elmer O. Cady,
Warden. The motion of petitioner for the appointment of counsel is
granted, and it is ordered that Irvin B. Charne, Esquire, of Milwau-
kee, Wisconsin, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 5798. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond Ham-
lin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. The motion of The National Legal
Aid and Defender Association to dispense with printing brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 6046. Don Richard Lego, petitioner, v. John Twomey, Warden.
The motion of petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Nathan Lewin, Esquire, of Washington, D.C.,
a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed
to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.

jurisdiction is noted.

Cordee Hahn. Motion to dispense with printing brief for respondent
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 1406. Charles Allan Broom, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted
and judgment reversed in light of this Court's decision in Whiteley
v. Warden, 401 U.S., decided March 29, 1971.
No. 1424. Annie C. Gornto, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for writ
cf certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted and judgment reversed.
No. 1436. Humble Oil & Refining Company, petitioner, v. I. R.
Price et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Harlan took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1971
500
No. 1467. ITT Lamp Division of the International Telephone and
Telegraph Corporation, petitioner, v. Stephen A. Minter, Commis-
sioner of the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare. Motion
of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied.

Patterson, Warden, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
White are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 6310. Jack Kelm, petitioner, v. Wayne K. Patterson. Warden.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.

etc., et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.

501

titioner for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis granted.
Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 3, 1971, until Mon-
day, May 17, 1971.

OPINIONS
No. 515. United States, petitioner, v. Southern Ute Tribe or Band
of Indians. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court
of Claims for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 600. Alcides Perez, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 154. Ronald James et al., appellants, v. Anita Valtierra et al.;
and
No. 226. Virginia C. Shaffer, appellant, v. Anita Valtierra et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Cali-

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1971
507
fornia for dismissal of the complaint. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 507. California Department of Human Resources Development
et al., appellants, v. Judith Java et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 758. United States, petitioner, v. Raymond J. Ryan. Argued
by Mr. Jerome Feit for the petitioner and by Mr. Herbert J. Miller,
Jr., for the respondent.
No. 557. United States, appellant, v. International Minerals &
Chemical Corporation. Argued by Mr. John F. Dienelt for the appel-
lant, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Harold E.
Spencer for the appellee.
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. Argued
on Exceptions to Report of Special Master by Mr. Peter L. Strauss
for the defendant and by Mr. Dallin W. Jensen for the plaintiff.
Adjourned until Monday, May 3, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
×

་
MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
508
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 973. Arthur K. Bolton, as Attorney General of the State of
Georgia, et al., appellants, v. Mary Doe; and
No. 6172. Unborn Child of Mary Doe, appellant, v. Mary Doe et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Georgia. The motion of the appellee in No. 973 for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The appeals are dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Gunn v. University Committee to End the War in
Vietnam et al., 399 U.S. 383 (1970).
No. 1136. Alvin Clark, appellant, v. Henry Ellenbogen et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37,
Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided
February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 1193. John Lane, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from County
Court at Law No. 1 of Travis County, Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted.
No. 1457. Rheba N. McMillan, appellant, v. Federal National
Mortgage Association. Appeal from the Appellate Department of the
Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdic-
tion should be noted.
No. 1230. Joseph Abodeely, appellant, v. Iowa. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
430-278-71-107

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
509
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1354. Ewald B. Nyquist, Commissioner of Education of the
State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Donald R. Lee, et al.; and
No. 1365. Frank P. Chropowicki et al., appellants, v. Donald R.
Lee et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the West-
ern District of New York. Judgment affirmed. The Chief Justice, Mr.
Justice Black and Mr. Justice Harlan are of the opinion that probable.
jurisdiction should be noted and cases set for oral argument.
No. 5050. Joyce Frederick et al., appellants, v. Irving Schwartz,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Connecticut. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Connecticut for
reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in Boddie v. Con-
necticut, 401 U.S. 371. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Doug-
las is of the opinion that the judgment should be reversed. Boddie v.
Connecticut, supra.
No. 5208. June Daniels Beverly, appellant, v. Scotland Urban
Enterprises, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas.
No. 6367. Michael David Campbell, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
-
No. 3. Major Walter Cobb and Thomas Spivey, petitioners, v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in Leary v. United
States, 395 U.S. (1969), and United States v. United States Coin and
Currency, 401 U.S. _, decided April 5, 1971.
No. 8. Wilbur Dean et al., petitioners, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in
light of this Court's decision in United States v. United States Coin
and Currency, 401 U.S., decided April 5, 1971.
No. 455. William Scott, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
,
510
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in United States v.
United States Coin and Currency, 401 U.S. — decided April 5, 1971.
No. 285. Stoy Decker, petitioner, v. United States. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light
of this Court's decisions in Haynes v. United States, 390 U.S. 85 (1968,
and United States v. United States Coin and Currency, 401 U.S.
decided April 5, 1971.
No. 1073. United States, petitioner, v. Frank Zizzo. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration
in light of this Court's decision in Mackey v. United States, 401 U.S.
―, decided April 5, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from this
action of the Court.
No. 1150. Floyd G. Bloss, petitioner, v. Michigan. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed. Redrup v. New York,
386 U.S. 767 (1967). The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr.
Justice Blackmun would grant the petition and set the case for oral
argument on the issue of whether the seizure of the film without a war-
rant violated applicable constitutional standards.
No. 5016. Richard A. Lauchli, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light
of this Court's decisions in Haynes v. United States, 390 U.S. 85
(1968), and United States v. United States Coin and Currency, 401
U.S., decided April 5, 1971.
No. 5052. Geodice Gillespie, petitioner, v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of this
Court's decisions in Haynes v. United States, 390 U.S. (1968), and
United States v. United States Coin and Currency, 401 U.S.
decided April 5, 1971.

bons, Clerk, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme

remanded to the Supreme Court of Arizona for reconsideration in light
of this Court's decision in Boddie v. Connecticut, 401 U.S. 371. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the
judgment should be reversed. Boddie v. Connecticut, supra.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Johnnie Pruett, petitioner, v. Texas. The application for
a stay is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart is of the opinion that the appli-
cation should be granted.
No. 45, Original. State of Washington et al., plaintiffs, v. General
Motors Corporation et al. The motion for leave to file a bill of com-
plaint is set for oral argument. One hour is allowed for oral argu-
ment. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this matter.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of Arkan-
sas. The application for a stay of the proceedings in the Chancery
Court of Chicot County, Arkansas, in the suit of Arkansas Land &
Cattle Company et al. v. Anderson-Tully Company, Civil Action
No. 10177, is referred to the Special Master for a report and recom-
mendation.
No. 49, Original. State of Illinois, plaintiff, v. City of Milwaukee,
Wisconsin, et al.; and
No. 50, Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff, v. State of New
York et al. The motions for leave to file bills of complaint are set
for oral argument. One hour is allowed for oral argument in each
☐ case.
No. 87. United States, petitioner, v. District Court in and for the
County of Eagle and State of Colorado et al.; and
No. 812. United States, petitioner, v. The District Court in and
Water Division No. 5, State of Colorado, et al. The motions of Fort
Mojave Tribe of Indians for leave to file suggestion of interest are
denied.
No. 346. First National City Bank, petitioner, v. Banco Nacional
de Cuba. The motion of the respondent for waiver of clerk's costs
is denied. Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stew-
art, and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that the motion
should be granted.
No. 6458. Carl Bruce Harris, petitioner, v. Texas. Counsel for pe-
titioner is directed to file a brief in support of petition on or before
May 20, 1971. The Attorney General of the State of Texas is invited
to file a responsive brief within ten days from the date of the receipt
of the petitioner's brief.

that probable jurisdiction should be noted for the reasons set forth in
opinion in No. 5048.

No. 982. Robert Y. Eckels, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Delores Ross
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of
Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, 401 U.S. —,
and its companion cases, decided April 20, 1971.
No. 1272. Mae Caldwell et al., petitioners, v. Donald Craighead,
as Band Instructor at Lebanon High School, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
523
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1334. Milton Silverman, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 1449. Frank Cacciatore Ippolito, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit denied.
No. 1455. Frank Peter Balistrieri, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 1520. Warren Pinto, Superintendent, New Jersey State Prison
Farm, petitioner, v. Esaw Mitchell. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 5004. Jose Verdugo, petitioner, v. United States. Motion for
leave to supplement petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 5048. Yvette Meltzer and Marcy Stine, petitioners, v. C. Buck
LeCraw & Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Georgia denied. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 5053. Manuel Leyva Lopez, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 5054. Raymond J. Bourbeau, Sr., petitioner, v. Joanne J.
Bourbeau Lancaster. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior
Court of Connecticut, Fairfield County, denied. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas.
No. 6375. Constance Kaufman, petitioner, v. Leland C. Carter,
Chief Probation Officer, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court
of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, denied. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Black. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 5210. Tina Deal, a minor by Frank L. Deal, et al., petitioners,
v. Cincinnati Board of Education. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied as
untimely filed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
524
No. 5795. Alan Dean Hudson, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 5971. In the Matter of Athen Carlton Garland et al., peti-
tioners. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit denied. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Brennan is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 5986. Ben Hickman, petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 6514. Robert Hortencio, petitioner, v. Calvin C. Whitehead,
Chief of Police, Salt Lake City, Utah. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Utah denied as untimely filed. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice Douglas dissent from the denial of the petition.

ent, Marion Correctional Institution, et al.; and
No. 6775. Victor F. Szijarto, petitioner, v. Louis S. Nelson, War-

denied.
No. 6913. Wiley R. Fallon, petitioner, v. W. E. Waggonner, Sher-
iff, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus
for other relief denied.
