OPINIONS
No. 108. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education, and
Welfare, petitioner, v. Pedro Perales. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Western District of Texas to determine whether the Secretary's
findings, in the light all amerial proffered and admissible, are sup-
ported by "substantial evidence" within the command of § 205 (g).
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
No. 338. Blonder-Tongue Laboratories, Inc., petitioner, v. Univer-
sity of Illinois Foundation et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Illinois for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 534. United States, appellant, v. Norman George Reidel. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Central District of
California. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Central District of California for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment in this case and
dissenting in No. 133, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black
with whom Mr. Douglas joins in this case and in No. 133, post.
No. 133. United States, appellant, v. Thirty-Seven (37) Photo-
graphs, Milton Luros, Claimant. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Central District of California. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1971
534
Central District of California for further proceedings consistent with
the opinion of this Court. Mr. Justice White announced the judgment
of the Court and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan concurring in the judgment and in Part I of Mr.
Justice White's opinion. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring
in the judgment and in Part I of Mr. Justice White's opinion. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with whom Mr. Justice Douglas
joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall dissenting in this case and
concurring in No. 534, ante.
No. 203. Dennis Councle McGautha, petitioner, v. California. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California; and
No. 204. James Edward Crampton, petitioner, v. Ohio. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgments affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Harlan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black concurring in the
judgments and in substantially all of the Court's opinion. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall join in No. 204. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, May 17, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
✓

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1971
535
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Harlan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 707. United States, appellant, v. 119 Cartons Containing
30,000 Obscene Magazines, Scan Imports, Claimant. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Central District of Califor-
nia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Central District of California for reconsideration
in light of this Court's decision in United States v. Thirty-Seven
(37) Photographs, Milton Luros, Claimant, 401 U.S. -, decided
May 3, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from this action of the
Court.
No. 728. Jane E. Hodgson et al., appellants, v. William Randall,
Ramsey County Attorney, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 729. Jane E. Hodgson, appellant, v. Minnesota. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1510. Airwick Industries, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Carlstadt
Sewerage Authority et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 6750. Alvin C. Gray, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
430-278-71-111

7
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1971
536
No. 1273. William Stafford, Sr., appellant, v. Michigan. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr.
Justice Black dissents from this action of the Court.
No. 1473. G & M Employment Service, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Department of Labor and Industries et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Judicial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 1501. Edward J. Kollar and James D. Kriegh, appellants, v.
City of Tucson et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Arizona. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice White are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction
should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 1514. Leitchfield Manufacturing Company, Inc., et al., appel-
lants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1538. Janie Passel et al., appellants, v. Fort Worth Inde-
pendent School District et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals
of Texas, Second Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 6054. Julio Vasquez, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from the
Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial
Department. The appeal is dismissed. Molinaro v. New Jersey, 396 U.S.
365 (1970). Mr. Justice Brennan is of the opinion that probable juris-
diction should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
No. 6778. Roberto Torres and Walter Dinger, appellants, v. New
York State Department of Labor et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York for reconsideration in light
of this Court's decision in California Department of Human Resources
v. Java, 401 U.S. __ decided April 26, 1971.
--
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 111. United States, petitioner, v. David Henry Holmes. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration
in light of this Court's decision in Ehlert v. United States, 401 U.S.

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1971
537
decided April 21, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from this
action of the Court.
No. 611. Melvin Laird et al., petitioners, v. Joseph Capobianco.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for recon-
sideration in light of this Court's decision in Ehlert v. United States,
401 U.S. decided April 21, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents
from this action of the Court.
,
No. 928. Evco dba Evco Instructional Designs, petitioner, v. Frank-
lin Jones, Commissioner of the Bureau of Revenue of the State of New
Mexico, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of New Mexico. In view of the concessions made in the brief in opposi-
tion filed by the Attorney General of New Mexico, and on examination
of the record, petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico for recon-
sideration in light of the position asserted by the Attorney General
in the brief in opposition. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Black, Mr.
Justice Harlan, and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the opinion that
certiorari should be denied.
No. 6584. Anthony Lewis Griffin, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Pursuant to the suggestion of the Solicitor General, petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky
for reconsideration in light of the position asserted by the Solicitor
General in the memorandum for the United States.
ORDERS IN Pending CASES
No. Michael R. Turpin et al., petitioners, v. Stanley R. Resor,
Secretary of the Army, et al. The application for a stay presented to
Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the stay should be granted.
No. Louis S. Kerr, petitioner, v. Ohio. The application for
a stay presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. 109. Time, Incorporated, petitioner, v. Frank Pape. The mo-
tion of the respondent to be relieved from payment of costs assessed
on reversal of judgment is denied.
No. 1009. United States, petitioner, v. Unicorn Enterprises, Inc.,
etc. The application for suspension of stay of mandate of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit pending the judgment

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1971
538
of this Court, presented to Mr. Justice Harlan and by him referred
to the Court, is granted. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
No. 1042. Florence Diffenderfer and Nishan Paul, appellants, v.
Central Baptist Church of Miami, Florida, Incorporated, et al. The
motion of Protestants and other Americans United for Separation of
Church and State for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 1681. W. Thomas Holmes, petitioner, v. Arizona. The applica-
tion for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the
stay should be granted.
No. 6623. F. L. McKenzie, petitioner, v. Texas. Counsel for the
petitioner is directed to file a brief in support of the petition on or
before June 3, 1971. The Attorney General of the State of Texas is
invited to file a responsive brief within 10 days from the date of re-
ceipt of the petitioner's brief.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 706. United States, appellant, v. Various Articles of "Obscene"
Merchandise, Fred Cherry, Claimant. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York. In this case
probable jurisdiction is noted.

that certiorari should be granted.

tions for the District of Columbia et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Black, with whom Mr. Justice Douglas
joins, is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted on the basis

330 U.S. 75, 105 (1947).

OPINIONS
No. 362. Vincent Francis McGee, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

Х
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1971
572
No. 75. California, petitioner, v. Jonathan Todd Byers. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr.
Chief Justice Burger announced the Court's judgment and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall join.
No. 135. Organization for a Better Austin et al., petitioners, v.
Jerome M. Keefe. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan.
No. 712. Triangle Improvement Council et al., petitioners, v.
William S. Ritchie, Commissioner, State Road Commission of West
Virginia, et al. Writ dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, May 24, 1971, at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, MAY 20, 1971
573
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stew-
art, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Black-
mun.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 6945. Joe Spencer, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. The application
for stay and/or injunction referred to the Court by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan is denied.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
574
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 1262. George K. Wyman et al., appellants, v. Catherine Boddie
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1373. George K. Wyman, etc., et al., appellants, v. Julia Rosado
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1328. Woodrow Wilson Lashley, Sr., and Claire Anita Ryza,
appellants, v. Maryland. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals
of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 1504. James Giannatti et al., appellants, v. County of Los
Angeles. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun concur.
No. 6555. Emanuel Burton, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. It appears that the sentences
imposed under the judgment sought to be reviewed were concurrent
and the appeal is therefore dismissed.
No. 6588. Charles J. Pardo, Jr., appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
430-278-71- -117

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
575
No. 598, Misc., October Term, 1964. Robert M. Williamson, et al.,
petitioners, v. Annie Gilmer et al. The motion to recall and amend
order of this Court of January 18, 1965, is denied. The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 1. Henry Rogers Anderson, petitioner, v. Kentucky. The mo-
tion for a restraining order presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 910. Allied Chemical & Alkali Workers of America, Local
Union No. 1, petitioner, v. Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, Chem-
ical Division, et al.; and
No. 961. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Pitts-
burgh Plate Glass Company, Chemical Division, et al. The motion of
the Solicitor General or additional time for oral argument is granted
and 15 additional minutes is allotted for that purpose. The respondent
is likewise allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 1159. Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York,
as Liquidator of Manhattan Casualty Company, petitioner, v. Bank-
ers Life and Casualty Company et al. The motion of the Solicitor Gen-
eral for leave to permit the Securites and Exchange Commission to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of the peti-
tioner, is granted. Fifteen minutes is allowed for this purpose. The
respondent is also allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral
argument.
No. 1454. Philip J. Picard, petitioner, v. James J. Connor. The
motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that James J. Twohig, Esquire, of South Boston, Massachusetts, a
member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 6744. Laverne Carter et al., appellants, v. Wayne Stanton et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of Indiana. Motion of the appellant for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 6966. Michael Epps et al., appellants, v. Americo V. Cortese
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Pennsylvania. Motion of the appellants for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted and case set for oral argument immediately following No. 6060.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
CERTIORARI GRANTED
576
No. 1470. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, petitioner, v.
Richard Nemitz et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.
No. 1480. Rudolph Santobello, petitioner, v. New York. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Apellate Division of the Supreme Court
of New York, First Judicial Department, granted.
No. 1536. Wisconsin, petitioner, v. Jonas Yoder et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin granted.
No. 1289. Pipefitters Local Union No. 562 et al., petitioners, v.
United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 6401. Thomas Kirby, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District,
granted limited to Question 2 presented in the petition which reads as
follows:
"(2) Whether due process requires that an accused be advised of his
right to counsel prior to a pre-indictment showup at a police station
several hours after his arrest and forty-eight hours after the alleged
crime occurred."

United States et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart
is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted. Mr. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 1395. Carmine G. DeSapio, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Stewart are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted. Mr.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
580
No. 1531. Harvey Lee Davis, petitioner, v. The Members of Selec-
tive Service Board No. 30 of Dallas, Texas, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.
No. 1540. Frank Berzanskis, petitioner, v. Richard J. Daley et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 1543. Paul J. Nix, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 5157. Billy G. Chambers and Thomas H. Oxenreider, peti-
tioners, v. California. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 6106. Catherine Tarver, petitioner, v. Sidney Smith, Secre-
tary, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice
Brennan is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 6527. Robert L. Freeman, petitioner, v. Joseph J. Joiner et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District, denied. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas
are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 6828. Ernest Esco Mooney, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 6911. William H. Jackson, petitioner, v. Warden, Maryland
Penitentiary. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas
corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 6568. Mervin Carlos McKinney, petitioner, v. United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit et al. Motion for leave to
file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED

Jr., petitioner;

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
581
No. 6284. Donald E. Donovan, petitioner, v. United States et al.;
No. 6319. Irving Eugene Ney, petitioner, v. Harold V. Field,
Superintendent, California Men's Colony;
No. 6464. James Henry Eisenhardt, petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 6510. Eugene Cookmeyer, petitioner, v. Louisiana Department
of Highways. Petitions for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit beginning October 12, 1971, and
ending October 15, 1971, and for such additional time in advance
thereof to prepare for the trial of cases, or thereafter as may be re-
quired to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294
(a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28
U.S.C. § 295.
OKDER
Applications for admission to the Bar of the Court on written
motion which are received during the summer recess may be approved
by a Single Justice. Certificates of admission shall be issued forth-
with and all orders approving such applications shall be entered in the
Journal at the beginning of the following Term.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, June 1, 1971.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1971
OPINIONS
594
No. 464. Gainesville Utilities Department et al., petitioners, v.
Florida Power Corporation; and
No. 469. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida Power
Corporation. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun took no part in the decision of these cases.
No. 758. United States, petitioner, v. Raymond J. Ryan. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceeding in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 5586. Paul J. Bell, Jr., petitioner, v. R. H. Burson, Director,
Georgia Department of Public Safety. On writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeals of Georgia. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Georgia for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun concur in the result.
No. 840. Ib Otto Astrup, petitioner, v. Immigration and Naturali-
zation Service. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Cali-
fornia for further proceedings on Astrup's petition for naturalization.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Black.
No. 143. James Palmer, appellant, v. City of Euclid, Ohio. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Harlan concurs in
the result. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 5250. James Herman Bostic, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Tuesday, June 1, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
☑

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1971
595
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 1394. Granite Falls State Bank, appellant, v. William E.
Schneider, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Washington. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1574. Wyman C. Lowe, appellant, v. Andrew Young. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 6901. James Preston Swaney, appellant, v. North Carolina.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 6662. Lyle Nelson, petitioner, v. United States. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Pursuant to the suggestion of the Solicitor General, petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the position as-
serted by the Solicitor General in the Memorandum for the United
States. Application for bail referred to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
No. 6704. Bernard Gaines, petitioner, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Pursuant to the suggestion of the Solicitor General, petition for
430-278-71- -120

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1971
596
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the position
asserted by the Solicitor General in the Memorandum for the United
States.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 910. Allied Chemical & Alkali Workers of America, Local
Union No. 1, petitioner, v. Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, Chem-
ical Division, et al.; and
No. 961. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Pittsburgh
Plate Glass Company, Chemical Division, et al. The motion of the
National Council of Senior Citizens for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted.
No. 958. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida Power
& Light Company. The motion of Gainesville Utilities Department
et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 1622. WHDH, Inc., petitioner, v. Federal Communications
Commission et al.;
No. 1708. Charles River Civic Television, Inc., petitioner, v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission et al.; and
No. 1716. Greater Boston Television Corporation, petitioner, v.
Federal Communications Commission et al. The motion for expeditious
treatment of petitions for writs of certiorari is denied. The motion for
conditional revocation of stay is denied. The Chief Justice took no part
in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 1689. Johnnie Pruett, petitioner, v. Texas et al. The reapplica-
tion for a stay and for other relief is denied.
No. 5850. Georgia Townsend etc., appellants, v. Harold O. Swank,
Director, Illinois Department of Public Aid, et al.; and
No. 6000. Loverta Alexander et al., appellants, v. Harold O.
Swank et al. The motion for additional time for oral argument is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 1419. California Motor Transport Co. et al., petitioners, v.
Trucking Unlimited et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 6810. Alexander McClanahan, petitioner, v. Morauer & Hart-
zell, Inc., et al. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit granted.

the Seventh Circuit denied.

No. 1468. Steve Scott and Cinne Arts Theatre, Inc., petitioners, v.

denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
denied.

Inc., et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern
District, denied.

trator, Small Business Administration, et al. Motion to dispense with

States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied.

eration of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari

Burns. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.

OPINIONS
No. 759. United States, appellant, v. Armour & Co. and Greyhound
Corporation. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White join. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice Blackmum took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 5175. Adolfo Perez et ux., petitioners, v. David H. Campbell,
Superintendent, Motor Vehicle Division, Arizona Highway Depart-
ment, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun concurring in the result as to petitioner Emma
Perez and dissenting as to petitioner Adolfo Perez, in which Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice Stewart join.
No. 117. Dennis Coates et al., appellants, v. City of Cincinnati.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Dissenting opinion
by Justice White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join.
No. 336. Louis S. Nelson, Warden, petitioner, v. Joe J. B. O'Neil.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1971
608
No. 785. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The Nat-
ural Gas Utility District of Hawkins County, Tennessee. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 189. Chicago and North Western Railway Company, petitioner,
v. United Transportation Union. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to re-
turn the case to the United States District Court for the District of North.
✓ Ohio for the taking of such further evidence as the parties may deem
necessary and that court may find helpful in passing on the issues.
which the case presents in light of the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
White join.
No. 821. United States, appellant, v. Greater Buffalo Press, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of New York. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Western District of New York
for the drafting of a decree and the making of such additional findings
both as respects the consent decree and the Sylacauga Plant as may
be appropriate or necessary for an effective remedy. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 557. United States, appellant, v. International Minerals &
Chemical Corporation. Certified appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Ohio. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the South-
ern District of Ohio for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Harlan and
Mr. Justice Brennan join.
No. 835. Robert Kenneth Dewey, petitioner, v. Reynolds Metals
Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr.
Justice Harlan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 7, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
☑

THURSDAY, JUNE 3, 1971
609
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No.- _ Peggy J. Connor et al., appellants, v. Paul B. Johnson
et al. On application for stay. The motion for stay is granted and
the judgment below is stayed until June 14. The United States District
Court for the Southern District of Mississippi is instructed, absent
insurmountable difficulties, to devise and put into effect a single-
member district plan for Hinds County by that date. In light of this
disposition, the District Court is directed to extend the June 4 filing
date for legislative candidates from Hinds County to an appropriate
date so that those candidates and the State of Mississippi may act in
light of the new districts into which Hinds County will be divided.
Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Harlan join.

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1971
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 495. Antonio R. Gaytan et al., appellants, v. Clifton W. Cas-
sidy, Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western Dstrict of Texas. Motions of Gilbert Trujillo et al., for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Texas for reconsid-
eration in light of Bell v. Burson, Director, Georgia Department of
Public Safety, 402 U.S.
decided May 24, 1971.
,
No. 1269. Harold O. Swank, Director, Illinois Department of Pub-
lic Aid, appellant, v. Gladys Rodriguez et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Motion for
leave to amend jurisdictional statement and motion of appellees for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 1534. Ad Hoc Committee on Consumer Protection, appellant, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia. Motion to dispense with printing juris-
dictional statement granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 1590. Mueller Brass Company, appellant, v. Gross Income Tax
Division, Indiana State Department of Revenue. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 6171. Clarence Chappell et al., appellants, v. R. H. Burson et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Georgia. Motion of the appellants for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
430-278-71-122

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1971
611
States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for recon-
sideration in light of Bell v. Burson, Director, Georgia Department of
Public Safety, 402 U.S.
decided May 24, 1971.
'
No. 6594. Andrew Pollion et al., appellants, v. John E. Lewis, Sec-
retary of State of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Motion of appellants
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois for reconsideration in light of Bell v. Burson, Di-
rector, Georgia Department of Public Safety, 402 U.S. -, de-
cided May 24, 1971.
No. 6847. Ramon Romero et al., appellants, v. James D. Hodgson,
Secretary of Department of Labor, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California. Motion
of appellants for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable
jursidiction should be noted.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 6870. Ramon Cortez Castro, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of this
Court's decisions in Leary v. United States 395 U.S. 6 (1969), and
United States v. United States Coin and Currency, 401 U.S. 715.
No. 6453. Alfred Loren Wallace, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon consideration of the
suggestion of the Solicitor General and upon this Court's examination
of the documents submitted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California
to hear further testimony from members of the appeal board as to
the basis for their action and for the court to reconsider the case in
light of this Court's decision in McGee v. United States, 402
U.S. - decided May 17, 1971.
,

see. Petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of

the certiorari should be granted.

surance Companies et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Louisiana denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted.

629
OPINIONS
No. 798. United States et al., petitioners, v. Anne Goyne Mitchell
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 71. Samuel J. Abate, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Paul F. Mundt
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Harlan concurs in the result for the reasons stated in his separate
opinion in Whitcomb v. Chavis, decided today. Mr. Justice Stewart

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1971
630
concurs in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 548. Herbert L. Ely, Individually and as Chairman of the
Democratic Party of Arizona, appellant, v. Gary Peter Klahr et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Arizona. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr.
Justice Harlan concurs in the result upon the premises set forth in his
separate opinions in Whitcomb v. Chavis, decided today; Oregon v.
Mitchell, 400 U.S. 112, 152 (1970); and Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S.
533, 589 (1964). Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Black joins.
No. 92. Edgar D. Whitcomb, Governor of the State of Indiana,
appellant v. Patrick Chavis et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Indiana. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the South-
ern District of Indiana for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Mr. Justice White announced the judgment of
the Court and delivered an opinion for the Court with respect to Parts
I-VI, in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun join, and in which, as to
Part VII, Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 144. Eugene Griffin, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Lavon Brecken-
ridge et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi
for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice
Harlan.
No. 66. George A. Rosenbloom, petitioner, v. Metromedia, Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black
concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
joins. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1971
631
No. 299. Paul Robert Cohen, appellant, v. California. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California,
Second Appellate District, for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Black join. Mr. Justice White concurs in
paragraph 2 of Mr. Justice Blackmun's dissenting opinion.
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. On bill of
complaint. Utah is entitled to the decree for which it asks. Parties
invited to address themselves to proposed decree attached to the opinion
with the view of agreeing, if possible, upon the issues which have
now been settled by this litigation. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 96. A. T. Gordon et al., petitioners, v. Granville H. Lance et al.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Appeals of West
Virginia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Appeals of West Virginia for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Mr. Justice Harlan concurs in the result for the reasons stated
in his separate opinion in Whitcomb v. Chavis, decided today. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would affirm for the reasons
expressed in the opinion of the West Virginia Supreme Court of
Appeals, 170 S.E. 2d 783 (W.Va. 1969).
No. 79. Stella Connell, appellant, v. James M. Higginbotham et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join concurring in the
result.
No. 5485. Robert Johnson, petitioner, v. Mississippi. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, June 14, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
Х

FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 1971
632
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 1719. Lamar Life Broadcasting Company, petitioner, v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission et al. The application for a stay
of enforcement of orders of the Federal Communications Commis-
sion presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. 1773. Palmer C. Scafati, Superintendent, Massachusetts Cor-
rectional Institution, petitioner, v. Ronald Fisher. The application
for a stay of the order of the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit, dated June 4, 1971, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan,
and by him referred to the Court, is granted by the Court pending
further order.

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1971
633
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 1267. Macio Bernard Simpson, petitioner, v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida,
First District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First
District, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Blackmun dissent for the reasons given in the dissenting opinion of
the Chief Justice in Ashe v. Swenson, 397 U.S. 436, 460. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 52. Edgar D. Whitcomb, Governor of the State of Indiana, ap-
pellant, v. Patrick Chavis et al.; and
No. 53. John C. Ruckelshaus et al., appellants, v. Patrick Chavis
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Indiana. The appeals are dismissed. Gunn v. University
Committee to End the War in Vietnam et al., 399 U.S. 383 (1970),
Whitcomb v. Chavis et al., 401 U.S. -, decided June 7, 1971. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
No. 105. Paul L. Adams et al., appellants, v. The Board of Regents
of the State of Florida et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Middle District of Florida. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Middle District
of Florida for reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in
Connell v. Higginbotham, et al., 401 U. S. -, decided June 7, 1971.
430-278-71——126

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1971
634
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 147. John V. Rimarcik, appellant, v. J. Richard Johansen, as
City Clerk of Minneapolis, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Minnesota. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Minnesota for reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in
Gordon et al. v. Lance et al., 401 U.S. -, decided June 7, 1971. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 148. George C. Dodds, appellant, v. J. Richard Johansen, as
City Clerk of Minneapolis, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed.
Gunn v. University Committee to End the War in Vietnam et al., 399
U. S. 383 (1970). Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 523. E. A. Dee Bogert et al., appellants, v. Harry Kinzer, Clerk
of the City of Pocatello, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Idaho. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Gordon et al. v. Lance et al., 401 U.S. —, decided June 7, 1971.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 803. J. Roger Gunderson et al., appellants, v. Tom Adams, as
Secretary of State of Florida, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 887. Alvin C. Brenner et al., appellants, v. The School District
of Kansas City, Missouri, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed.
Gordon et al. v. Lance et al., 401 U.S. -, decided June 7, 1971. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 1645. Orleans Parish Board of Supervisors of Elections et al.,
appellants, v. Harold A. Dundee. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the
amendments to Sections 1909, 1931 and 1995 of Title 47 of the Louisi-
ana Revised Statutes of 1950, enacted by the Legislature of Louisiana
by Act No. 232 on July 2, 1970. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from this
action of the Court.

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1971
635
No. 1662. School District of the Township of Shaler et al., appel-
lants, v. Interim Operating Committee of Administrative Unit No.
5 et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 6947. Harold Strader, appellant, v. Kansas Public Employees
Retirement System. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petititon for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 6948. Robert L. Brewster, appellant, v. Lake Superior District
Power Company. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 641. Emmery Mihaly et al., petitioners, v. Elouise Westbrook
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
California. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for recon-
sideration in light of this Court's decision in Gordon et al. v. Lance
et al., 401 U.S. —, decided June 7, 1971. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 1656. Douglas Polsky, petitioner, v. Roderick Wetherill, etc.,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals pur-
suant to the recommendation of the Solicitor General in the Memo-
randum for the United States.
No. 6578. John C. Colton, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of
this Court's decisions in United States v. United States Coin and
Currency, etc., 401 U.S. 715 (1970), and Leary v. United States, 395
U.S. 6. (1969).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 316. Uniformed Sanitation Men Association, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Commissioner of Sanitation of the City of New York et al.
The motion to advance cause for immediate consideration is denied.

No. 958. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida Power
& Light Company. The motion of American Public Power Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice

Laborers' International Union of North America, AFL-CIO, for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, are granted.

Attorney General of Florida, et al. The motion to dispense with print-
ing amicus curiae brief of the National Legal and Defender Associa-
tion is granted.

et al., appellants, v. Lucretia Peteros Richardson. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. In this
case probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.

III

Arthur S. Zuckerman
The Chief Justice said:
"Today we wish to take note of the retirement of Edmund P. Cul-
linan, Chief Deputy Clerk of this Court, after 41 years of dedicated
services to the Court. Mr. Cullinan entered the service of the Court
in 1930, the same year that Charles Evans Hughes became Chief Jus-

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1971
646
tice. He has thus served with five of its 15 Chief Justices. Through
those years his conscientious and able performance of duty has con-
tributed immeasurably to the efficient operation of the Supreme Court.
"Thousands of litigants and countless members of the Bar of the
Court are indebted to him for his skillful and expeditious attention to
their problems, great and small. They are indebted to him, too, for his
unfailing courtesy and his capacity for sensitive understanding of
their individual needs and problems.
"These days we speak often of the importance of efficient court ad-
ministration. Edmund Cullinan labored more than four decades in that
cause, and he did it with unobtrusive loyalty and high professional
skill. No detail was ever too small to escape his thoughtful attention,
and no task ever too large to deter his conscientious efforts. Few
have ever equalled his grasp of procedure and practice before the
Supreme Court.
"His 41 years of honorable service with the Court have been uni-
formly characterized by the qualities of integrity and unswerving
devotion to duty that are indispensable to the efficient and fair admin-
istration of justice. His retirement is a loss to the Court and to all
who come here.
"I know I speak for all the members of the Court, and for our pred-
ecessors with whom he served, when I express our heartfelt thanks
to Edmund P. Cullinan as he leaves the institution he loved so well
and served so loyally; and he leaves with our best wishes for the
future."

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1971
OPINIONS
647
No. 544. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v. Lincoln
Savings and Loan Association. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 609. John O. Graham, Commissioner, Department of Public
Welfare, State of Arizona, appellant, v. Carmen Richardson, etc.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Arizona; and
No. 727. William P. Sailer et al., appellants, v. Elsie Mary Jane
Leger and Beryl Jervis. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgments affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Harlan joins in Parts
III and IV of the Court's opinion, and in the judgment of the Court.
No. 655. James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Local Union 6799, United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice White.
No. 76. Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and
Motor Coach Employees of America, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Wilson
P. Lockridge. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Idaho
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr.
Chief Justic Burger joins. Mr. Justice Blackmun also dissents for
the basic reasons set forth by Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
White in their respective dissenting opinions.
No. 107. Hazel Palmer et al., petitioners, v. Allen C. Thompson,
Mayor, City of Jackson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 21, 1971, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1971
648
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 122. Robert H. Fucini, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice
Douglas are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted
and the case set for oral argument.
No. 724. Alhambra City School District of Los Angeles County
et al., appellants, v. James S. Mize, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 1664. Desert Outdoor Advertising, Inc., appellant, v. Cali-
fornia. Appeal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court
of California, County of Riverside. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 953. Daniel Richard D., appellant, v. County of Onondaga.
Appeal from Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and the case set for oral
argument.
No. 1341. Jesse L. Jackson et al., appellants, v. Richard Ogilvie,
Governor of the State of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment
affirmed.
430-278-71—128

MONDAY, JUNĘ 21, 1971
649
No. 1360. Louis R. Beller et al., appellants, v. Reubin Askew,
Governor of the State of Florida, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 1383. United States, appellant, v. B & H Dist. Corp., et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Wisconsin. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin for recon-
sideration in light of this Court's decisions in United States v. Reidel,
402 U.S., and United States v. Thirty-seven Photographs, 302
U.S., decided May 3, 1971.
No. 1387. George Van Hoomissen et al., appellants, v. James A.
Hayse et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Oregon. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Oregon for reconsid-
eration in light of this Court's decisions in Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S.
37, Samuels v. Mackell and Fernandez v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66, decided
February 23, 1971. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the
judgment should be affirmed.
No. 1598. John V. Hoene et al., appellants, v. John R. Jamieson,
State Commissioner of Highways of the State of Minnesota, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 5078. In re Thomas E. Johnson, appellant. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Maryland. Motion of appellant for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice
Douglas are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted
and case set for oral argument.
No. 5667. Clarence J. DeBacker, appellant, v. Maurice Sigler. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska. Motion of appellant for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Black and Mr.
Justice Douglas are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 6364. Juana Perez Gonzales et al., appellants, v. Con F. Shea
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Colorado. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Colorado for reconsideration
in light of this Court's decisions in Graham, Commissioner, Depart-
ment of Public Welfare of Arizona v. Richardson and Sailer v. Leger,
403 U.S., decided June 14, 1971.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1971
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
650
No. 761. James S. Mize, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Alhambra City
School District of Los Angeles County et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted, judgments vacated and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of California for reconsideration in light of this Court's deci-
sion in Gordon v. Lance, 403 U.S. —, decided June 7, 1971.
No. 1305. Jim Baines, petitioner, v. City of Birmingham, Alabama.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Alabama. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for
reconsideration in light of this Court's decision in Cohen v. California,
403 U.S., decided June 7, 1971.
No. 5687. Clarence Tate, Jr., petitioner, v. Olin G. Blackwell. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of this
Court's decision in Griffiin v. Breckenridge, 403 U.S.
June 7, 1971.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
,
decided
No. . Elmer J. Dixon, petitioner, v. Oregon. The application
for stay and for continuance of bail, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 189. Chicago and North Western Railway Company, peti-
tioner, v. United Transportation Union. The motion of the respondent
to issue the judgment forthwith is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 538. Nellie Swarb et al., appellants, v. William M. Lennox
et al. The motion of the Pennsylvania Credit Union League for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of the National
Consumers Law Center for leave to dispense with printing the amicus
curiae brief is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of these motions.
No. 1184. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Plaster-
ers' Local Union No. 79, etc., et al.; and
No. 1231. Texas State Tile & Terrazzo Co., Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Plasterers' Local Union No. 79, etc., et al. The motion of the peti-
tioners for additional time for oral argument is granted and a total
of 15 additional minutes allotted for that purpose. The respondents are
also allotted 15 additional minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1971
651
No. 1331. Affiliated Ute Citizens of the State of Utah et al., pe-
titioners, v. United States et al. The motion of the Association on
American Indian Affairs, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 1332. Reliance Electric Company, petitioner, v. Emerson Elec-
tric Company. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and a total
of 15 minutes allotted for that purpose. The respondent is allotted 15
additional minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 1389. United States, petitioner, v. Forrest S. Tucker. The mo-
tion of the respondent for the appointment of counsel is granted and
it is ordered that William A. Norris, Esquire, of Los Angeles, Cali-
fornia, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 6158. Donald Lindsey et al., appellants, v. Dorothea M. Nor-
met et al. The motion of the Legal Aid Society of the Pima County
Bar Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 7158. Florence Digesualdo et al., appellants, v. Con F. Shea
et al. The motion to expedite consideration is denied. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 364. United States, appellant, v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Super
8mm. Film et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Central District of California. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.
No. 867. Millard Gooding, Warden, appellant, v. Johnny C. Wil-
son. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

No. 1773. Palmer C. Scafati, Superintendent, Massachusetts Cor-
rectional Institution, petitioner, v. Ronald Fisher. The stay entered
by this Court on June 11, 1971, is vacated. The order of June 4, 1971,
of the Court of Appeals that "Fisher will be ordered released as soon
as the district court can conduct a hearing" is vacated and set aside.
The provision of the order of the District Court entered July 13, 1970,
that petitioner be discharged unless "timely retried without use of
the tainted evidence," is reinstated and made effective from this date.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 28,
1971, upon which day it will adjourn for the term unless otherwise
ordered.

OPINIONS
No. 322. Joseph McKeiver and Edward Terry, appellants, v.
Pennsylvania. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District; and
No. 128. In re Barbara Burns et al., petitioners. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina. Judgments
affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun announced the judgments of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice White join. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in
No. 322 and dissenting in No. 128. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan
concurring in the judgments. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Doug-
las with whom Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1971
667
No. 5714. Linda Jenness et al., appellants, v. Ben W. Fortson,
Secretary of State of Georgia. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Harlan
concur in the result.
No. 323. Edward H. Coolidge, Jr., petitioner, v. New Hampshire.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New Hamp-
shire for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join in Parts II A, II B and
II C. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger dissenting in part and concurring in part. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Black concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
joins concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 301. Webster Bivens, petitioner, v. Six Unknown Named
Agents of Federal Bureau of Narcotics. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Black. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
No.
-
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
Peggy J. Connor et al., petitioners. v. Paul B. Johnson
et al. The application for further stay to enforce this Court's mandate
is denied.
Adjourned until Monday, June 28, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
Х

FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1971
668
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 1873. New York Times Company, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit granted and the case is set for oral argument
on Saturday, June 26, 1971, at 11:00 o'clock a.m. Briefs and records
shall be filed simultaneously, the requirement for printing being
waived.
The application of the New York Times Company for stay of man-
date of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is granted pend-
ing further order of this Court. The Special Appendix referred to
in the order of the Court of Appeals, and any additional items as
the United States may have specified with particularity, shall be
served on the New York Times Company and filed in this Court by
5:00 p.m. today, June 25, 1971. The restraint imposed upon the New
York Times by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is con-
tinued pending argument and decision in this case.
For purposes of argument this case is consolidated with No. 1885,
United States v. The Washington Post, petition for certiorari this day
granted. Portions of record or argument relating to matters claimed
to affect national security may be filed in sealed form.
Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the motion to vacate the order
of the Court of Appeals except insofar as it affirms the judgment of
the District, would not continue the restraint imposed upon the New
York Times by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and
would deny the petition for certiorari.
No. 1885. United States, petitioner, v. The Washington Post Com-
pany et al. Treating the application for stay as a petition for certiorari,
the petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit is granted and the case
is set for oral argument on Saturday, June 26, 1971, at 11 a.m. Briefs
and records shall be filed simultaneously, the requirement for printing
being waived. Portions of the record or argument relating to matters.
claimed to affect national security may be filed in sealed form.
430-278-71—131

FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1971
669
Pending argument and decision in this case the restraining imposed
by the Court of Appeals on the Washington Post and its officers, is
continued but limited to items specified in the special Appendix filed
on June 21, 1971, with the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit in a case in that Court captioned The United States v.
New York Times Company et al., Docket 71-1616, decide June 23,
1971, and any such additional items as the United States may have
specified with particularity by 5:00 p.m. today, June 25, 1971. Said
Appendix as supplemented shall be served on respondent Washington
Post and filed in this Court at that time.
For purposes of argument the case is consolidated with No. 1873,
New York Times Company v. United States, petition for certiorari
this date granted.
Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall would not continue the restraint, as limited or
otherwise, and, treating the application as a petition for certiorari,
would deny the petition.

1
SATURDAY, JUNE 26, 1971
670
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 1873. New York Times Company, petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 1885. United States, petitioner, 2. The Washington Post
Company et al.
The Chief Justice announced that the Government's motion to con-
duct part of the oral arguments involving security matters in camera
is denied and under the order granting the writ counsel may submit
arguments in writing under seal in lieu of the in camera oral argu-
ment. Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Blackmun and the Chief Justice
would grant limited in camera argument.
Two hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Solicitor
General Griswold for the United States, by Mr. Alexander M. Bickel
for The New York Times, and by Mr. William R. Glendon for the
Washington Post Company et al.
