430-278-71-132

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
671
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 5085. Charles Hunter and Franklin Wright, petitioners v.
Tennessee;
No. 5098. Ulous Harris, petitioner, v. Tennessee;
No. 5101. Garfield Houston and Earl Foster, petitioners, v. Ten-
nessee; and
No. 5103. Charles Hunter and Franklin Wright, petitioners v.
Tennessee. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Tennessee, Western Division. Motions for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petitions for writs of certiorari granted. Judgments va-
cated and cases remanded to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, West-
ern Division, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Black dissents.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 517. The Board of Education of the County of Kanawha et al.,
appellants, v. Miles Hughes. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ap-
peals of West Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of
che opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set
for oral argument.
No. 852. John A. Kervick, State Treasurer of New Jersey, appel-
lant, v. Joseph E. Clayton et al.; and
No. 858. Howard Levine et al., appellants, v. Joseph E. Clayton
et al. Appeals from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment
vacated and cases remanded to the Supreme Court of New Jersey for
reconsideration in light of this Court's decisions in Lemon et al. v.
Kurtzman et al., 403 U. S. -, Tilton et al. v. Richardson et al., 403
480-278-711-
-133

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
672
U. S., Earley et al., v. DiCenso et al., 403 U. S., and Robinson
et al v. DiCenso et al., 403 U. S. -, decided June 28, 1971. Mr. Justice
Black is of the opinion that the judgment should be reversed. Mr.
Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 934. Americans United, Incorporated as Protestants and other
Americans United for Separation of Church and State, et al., ap-
pellants, v. Independent School District No. 622, Ramsey County,
Minnesota, et al.; and
No. 935. Matthew Stark, etc., appellant, v. Duane J. Mattheis, Com-
missioner of Education of the State of Minnesota, et al. Appeals from
the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeals are dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and cases set for oral argument.
No. 1329. Richard W. Hunt, appellant, v. Robert E. McNair,
Governor of the State of South Carolina, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of South Carolina. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for reconsideration
in light of this Court's decisions in Lemon et al. v. Kurtzman et al.,
403, U.S.
Tilton et al. v. Richardson et al., 403 U.S.
Earley et al. v. DiCenso et al., 403 U.S.
and Robinson et al. v.
DiCenso et al., 403 U.S.
decided June 28, 1971. Mr. Justice
Black and Mr. Justice Douglas are of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted and the case set for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 48. Larry Hudson, petitioner, v. Louisiana. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Petition for
writ of certiorari dismissed. See Molinaro v. New Jersey, 396 U.S. 365
(1970).
No. 129. Jerry Ralph Adams, petitioner, v. Washington. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Motion of respond-
ent to dispense with printing response granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment, insofar as it imposes the death sentence,
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Washington for
further proceedings. Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510 (1968);
Boulden v. Holman, 394 U.S. 478 (1969); and Maxwell v. Bishop, 398
U.S. 262 (1970). Mr. Justice Black dissents.
No. 5006. Marvin Reginald Mathis, petitioner, v. New Jersey. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
673
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment, insofar as it imposes the death
sentence, reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New
Jersey for further proceedings. Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510
(1968) Boulden v. Holman, 394 U.S. 478 (1969); and Maxwell v.
Bishop, 398 U.S. 262 (1970). Mr. Justice Black dissents.
No. 5015. Ben T. Mathis, petitioner, v. Alabama. On petition for

to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment, insofar as it imposes the death sentence, reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further
proceedings. Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510 (1968); Boulden
v. Holman, 394 U.S. 478 (1969); and Maxwell v. Bishop, 398 U.S.
262 (1970). Mr. Justice Black dissents.

No. 5142. Peter J. Ladetto, petitioner, v. Massachusetts. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment, insofar as it imposes the
death sentence, reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial
Court of Massachusetts for further proceedings. Witherspoon v.
Illinois, 391 U.S. 510 (1968); Boulden v. Holman, 394 U.S. 478
(1969); and Maxwell v. Bishop, 398 U.S. 222 (1970) Mr. Justice
Black dissents.

of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment, insofar as it imposes the death sentence,
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Texas for further proceedings. Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510
(1968); Boulden v. Holman, 394 U.S. 478 (1969); and Maxwell v.
Bishop, 398 U.S. 262 (1970). Mr. Justice Black dissents.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The joint motion of the United States and the State of
Florida to initiate supplemental proceedings is granted. The motion
of the United States and the State of Florida to consolidate proceed-
ings is granted. The motion of the United States and the State of
Florida to appoint a Special Master is granted.
It is ordered that the Honorable Albert B. Maris, Senior Judge of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, be, and he
is hereby appointed Special Master to conduct supplemental proceed-
ings which shall be docketed as case No. 52 Original. The Special Mas-
ter shall have authority to fix the time and conditions for filing of
additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and author-
ity to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as
may be introduced and such as he may deem it necessary to call for.
The master is directed to submit such reports as he may deem
appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his reports, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master becomes
vacant during the recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall have au-

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
679
thority to make a new designation which shall have the same effect as
if orginally made by the Court herein.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of the matters in this case.
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The motion by the United States to dismiss the counterclaim and deny
the demand for jury trial filed by the State of Florida is received and
filed and the State of Florida is allowed 60 days to respond. Upon re-
ceipt of the response of the State of Florida, the motion and response
shall be referred to the Special Master for his report and recommenda-
tion. The joint motion of the United States and the State of Florida to
consolidate proceedings herein against the State of Florida with
United States v. State of Louisiana et al., No. 9 Original, is granted.
The report of the Special Master upon the motion of the State of
Florida for a severance is received and filed, and the motion of the
State of Florida for a severance is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of these matters.
No. 45, Original. State of Washington et al., plaintiffs, v. General
Motors Corporation et al. The motion of the State of Idaho to be
named as a party plaintiff is granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of Ar-
kansas. The report of the Special Master contained in his letter dated
May 12, 1971, to the Clerk of this Court, is approved and it shall be
filed with the Clerk.
No. 203. Dennis Councle McGautha, petitioner, v. California; and
No. 204. James Edward Crampton, petitioner, v. Ohio. The issu-
ance of the mandate of this Court in each of these cases is hereby stayed
pending disposition of the petitions for rehearing.
No. 1606. Martin Dies, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Van Phillip Carter
et al. The motion of appellee Pate for an enlargement of time for oral
argument is granted and an additional ten minutes is allotted to
the appellees to be divided equally between counsel for appellee Pate
and counsel for appellee Wischkaemper. An additional ten minutes for
oral argument is also allotted to counsel for the appellants. Pursuant to
further motion of appellee Pate, the total time allotted to appellees
for oral argument is divided equally between counsel for appellee Pate
and counsel for appellee Wischkaemper, so that each will have 20
minutes.
No. 5161. Frank Johnson, appellant, v. Louisiana; and
No. 5338. Robert Apodaca, Harry Morgan Cooper, Jr., and James
Arnold Madden, petitioners v. Oregon. These cases are restored to the
calendar for reargument.
480-278-71-135

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
680
No. 5712. George William Milton, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Division of Corrections. The motion of
the petitioner for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Neil P. Rutledge, Esquire, of Durham, North Carolina, a member
of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 6623. F. L. McKenzie, petitioner, v. Texas. The period of time
for filing a brief in support of the petition for certiorari is hereby, ex-
tended to July 18, 1971. The Attorney General of the State of Texas
is invited to file a responsive brief within 10 days from the date of re-
ceipt of the petitioner's brief.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 5025. Donald Felix Schneble, petitioner, v. Florida. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida granted limited to the ques-
tion whether petitioner's conviction was in violation of Bruton v.
United States, 391 U.S. 123 (1968).
No. 5049. Earnest James Aikens, Jr., petitioner, v. California. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California limited to the follow-
ing question:
"Does the imposition and carrying out of the death penalty in this
case constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments?"
No. 5059. John Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia granted limited to the fol-
lowing question:
"Does the imposition and carrying out of the death penalty in this
case constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments?"
No. 5133. Lucious Jackson, petitioner, v. Georgia. Motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Georgia granted limited to the following
question:
"Does the imposition and carrying out of the death penalty in this
case constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments?"
No. 5135. Elmer Branch, petitioner, v. Texas. Motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
681
to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas granted limited to the fol-
lowing question:
"Does the imposition and carrying out of the death penalty in this
case constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments?"
No. 5056. Lyman A. Moore, petitioner, v. Illinois. Motion of
American Civil Liberties Union, Illinois Division, and Illinois Com-
mittee for the Abolition of Capital Punishment for leave to file a
brief, as amici curiae, granted. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Illinois granted limited to Questions 1, 3 and 4 set fourth in the
petition which read as follows:
"1. Petitioner was sentenced to death for murder. Six items of
exonerating evidence were not disclosed to him at trial. The court
below affirmed on the ground that the prosecution's duty to disclose
exonerating evidence depends upon a request; that the prosecutor had
shown his entire file to defense counsel at trial and no further request
for disclosure was made. None of the exonerating items was con-
tained in said file. Trial defense counsel were ignorant of the existence
of the suppressed information.
"Questions presented are:
"(a) Whether a request is an indispensable prerequisite to
disclosure of exonerating evidence by the State?
"(b) Whether material evidence favorable to an accused
should be disclosed by the State without a request where such
evidence is not recorded?
"(c) Whether denial of due process of law is contingent upon
a request where a State knowingly permits false testimony to
remain uncorrected?
"(d) Where a prosecutor shows his entire file to defense coun-
sel at trial, but none of the exonerating items of evidence are
contained in said file, does that satisfy the prosecution's duty of
disclosure?
"(e) Whether nondisclosure of the prosecuting police depart-
ment is imputable to the prosecution?
"3. The deceased was killed with a twelve-gauge shotgun. The
Chicago Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory determined that he
was killed with a twelve-gauge shotgun. (A.139.) The prosecutor
stated in a Bill of Particulars that the murder weapon was a twelve-
gauge shotgun. (A.2.)
Over objection (A.81-94), the prosecution introduced a sixteen-
gauge shotgun into evidence. (A.94.) The sixteen-gauge shotgun did
not belong to the petitioner, was not recovered from him, and was
never in his possession or control. (A.58, 66–71.)

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
682
During closing argument the prosecutor told the jury that the
sixteen-gauge shotgun was not the weapon that killed the deceased,
but that any man who was with another man who had the shotgun
and shells for it was the type of person that deserved the death
penalty. (A.191–201, 204–206.)
The question presented is whether the introduction and use of
such evidence, totally unconnected with the petitioner or the crime
charged, denied the petitioner a fair trial?
"4. Eight veniremen were removed for cause when they voiced
general objections to capital punishment or stated that they had
religious or conscientious scruples against the death penalty in a
proper case.
"In the light of Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510, may a state
court of review affirm a death sentence,
"(a) on the ground that the tenor of voir dire examination
was unlike that of Witherspoon?
"(b) on the ground that the prosecution had sufficient per-
emptory challenges to have eliminated those prospective jurors
eligible to serve under Witherspoon?"
CERTIORARI DENIED

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
ORDER
683
It is ordered that Michael Rodak, Jr., be, and he is hereby, appointed
Chief Deputy Clerk of this Court.
ORDER
It is ordered that the following allotment be made of the Chief
Justice and Associate Justices of this Court among the circuits, pur-
suant to Title 28, United States Code, Section 42, and that such allot-
ment be entered of record, viz:
For the District of Columbia Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief
Justice,
For the First Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate
Justice,
For the Second Circuit, John M. Harlan, Associate Justice,
For the Third Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate
Justice,
For the Fourth Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice,
For the Fifth Circuit, Hugo L. Black, Associate Justice,
For the Sixth Circuit, Potter Stewart, Associate Justice,
For the Seventh Circuit, Thurgood Marshall, Associate Justice,
For the Eighth Circuit, Harry A. Blackmun, Associate Justice,
For the Ninth Circuit, William O. Douglas, Associate Justice,
For the Tenth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice.
It is further ordered that when the Circuit Justice is unavailable
to act on an application in a case arising in his circuit, the Clerk
shall present such application to the Acting Circuit Justice.
The Acting Circuit Justice, for this purpose, is that Justice, then
available, who is next junior to the Circuit Justice; except that
the turn of the Chief Justice in this cycle shall follow that of the
Justice most recently appointed.

Schuyler, Jr.
No. 30. United States, petitioner, v. Roosevelt Hudson Harris. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this
Court. Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the Court's judgment
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join. Mr. Justice Stewart joins in Part I of the Court's
opinion and in the judgment. Mr. Justice White agrees with Part III
of the Court's opinion and has concluded that the affidavit, considered
as a whole, was sufficient to support the issuance of the warrant. He
therefore concurs in the judgment of reversal. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Black. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Harlan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 89. Alton J. Lemon et al., appellants, v. David H. Kurtzman, as
Superintendent of Public Instruction of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; and
No. 569. John R. Earley et al., appellants, v. Joan DiCenso et al.;
and
No. 570. William P. Robinson, Jr., Commissioner of Education of
the State of Rhode Island, et al., appellants, v Joan DiCenso et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1971
688
Rhode Island. Judgment reversed in No. 89 and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Judgment affirmed in Nos. 569 and 570. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Black joins and with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins as to
Nos. 569 and 570. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part
and dissenting in part in these cases and in No. 153, post. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White concurring in part in the judgment in No. 89, dissent-
ing in Nos. 569 and 570, and concurring in the result in No. 153,
post. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of No. 89.
No. 153. Eleanor Taft Tilton et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Rich-
ardson, Secretary of the United States Department of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Connecticut. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the Court's judgment and deliv-
ered an opinion in which Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan con-
curring in part and dissenting in part in this case and in Nos. 89, 579
and 570, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the result
in this case, concurring in the judgment in No. 89, ante, and dissenting
in Nos. 569 and 570, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 783. Cassius Marsellus Clay, Jr., also known as Muhammad
Ali, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr.
Justice Harlan concurs in the result. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
"The Court will take a recess pending further order of the Court.”

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1971

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Black, Mr. Justice
Harlan, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 1596. William J. Sanders, Secretary of the State Board of
Education of Connecticut, et al., appellants, v. Rita Johnson et al.; and
No. 1624. James Buckley et al., appellants, v. Rita Johnson et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of
Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Josephine Goss et al., petitioners, v. Board of Education
of the City of Knoxville, Tennessee, et al. Petitioners' motion for an
immediate order requiring the submission of a plan for the desegrega-
tion of the Knoxville school system for the 1971-1972 school year and
for an order requiring the District Court to hold timely hearings, enter
such orders and entertain such proceedings as may be necessary to
achieve a unitary school system in Knoxville by the commencement of
the 1971-1972 school year was presented to Mr. JUSTICE STEWART and
by him referred to the Court. The motion is denied. The United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee has not had an
opportunity since the June 22, 1971, remand of the case by the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to inquire whether
respondents have failed to maintain a unitary school system as defined
in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, 402 U.S. 1
(1971), and prior cases. Of course, the District Court must conduct
forthwith such proceedings as may be required for the prompt deter
mination of this question, and, should it find that respondents have not
maintained a unitary school system, respondents must "terminate dual
school systems at once. . . ." Alexander v. Holmes County Board of
Education, 396 U. S. 19 (1969). The mandate of the Court of Appeals
should issue forthwith.
480-278-71-136

No.
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1971
690
Edward S. Friedland, petitioner, v. Justices of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, en banc. The
application for extraordinary relief is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 577. United States, petitioner, v. Sandra Denise Johnson. This
case is restored to the calendar for reargument. In their briefs and
oral arguments, counsel are requested to discuss, in addition to the
question specified in the original petition, the following:
"What relevance has the doctrine of Vitarelli v. Seaton, 359 U.S.
535, to the legality of the search in the present case?"
OPINION
No. 1873. New York Times Company, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit; and
No. 1885. United States, petitioner v. The Washington Post Com-
pany et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment in No. 1885 affirmed.
The order of the United States Court for the Second Circuit in No.
1873 reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit with directions to enter a judgment
affirming the judgment of the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. The stays entered June 25, 1971, by
the Court are vacated. The judgments shall issue forthwith. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Black with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice
Black joins. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice White joins.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart joins. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Harlan with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases and all matters submitted to the Court at this term, and
ready for disposition, have been disposed of and,
"It is therefore ordered that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
